https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89073,2019,Sustainability Grand Challenges,"Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. C Frey - Heger'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This module focuses on the sustainability grand challenges of our times. Sustainability grand challenges can refer to ecological as well as social problems, such as climate change, land degradation and natural disasters or global displacement, poverty and inequality. In most scenarios, it is a complex configuration of both. Grand challenges are global problems that require combined efforts and new innovative approaches to better understand and tackle them and the main learning goal of this course is collaboration in understanding and solving grand challenges.

Participants will collaborate to analyze sustainability grand challenges and how solutions may be formulated engaging multiple stakeholders and by thinking ‘out-of-the-box’.  Critically in this module, participants are required to work together creating a novel and commercially viable business solution to a real-world ‘sustainability case’. The case organization for 2019 is Commonland and its partner Wide Open Architecture in Australia (Previous cases include Heineken (2015), Boskalis (2016), Commonland/WIJ.Land (2017&2018)).

Participants will thus work in teams and under significant time pressure to analyze the sustainability grand challenge and jointly formulate a credible ‘solution’. Groups will elaborate on their solution in a joint report as well as a presentation to a multi-stakeholder jury.
For this, groups will need to apply their learning of structuring and delivery of a message in time-restricted and context-sensitive ‘pitching’ format. Here, a ‘winning team’ will be selected.
Participants should attend and actively participate in the classes, are expected to engage in class discussions, ask questions of speakers, and demonstrate involvement with the in-class exercises.
Participation in the sessions is mandatory.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, the participant is able to:

column2: • Collaborate in analyzing a sustainability grand challenge using different theoretical frameworks and tools such as stakeholder management and innovation thinking
• Collaborate in developing practical solutions to the sustainability grand challenge, reflecting on the viability of the solution and summarizing those in a final report
• Jointly deliver a presentation pitch suitable for the boardroom

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: With the global population growing to 9.7 billion people, the World Business Council for Sustainable Development forecasts that if organizations do not drastically revise their way of doing business, humanity will be consuming the ecological resources of 2.3 earths in 2050. To avert the disaster that would ensue, organizations need to foster sustainable development by helping to meet the needs of the present generation without compromising the needs of future generations. This requires a focus not only on economic, but also on environmental and social performance.

Such a focus is not self-evident. Think of high-profile scandals such as the Enron, Worldcom, and Parmalat debacles, not to mention the global banking crisis. The economic, social, and environmental consequences of such drastic, moral transgressions may be so profound that they potentially nullify any sustainable development. Yet even for the many organizational members—CEOs and employees alike—that do embrace sustainability, dilemmas and challenges arise: When should environmental outcomes prevail over social outcomes? How much should we rely on technological solutions? How can we and our stakeholders bridge the gap between good intentions and good behavior? These issues show that sustainability and ethics go hand in hand, and that both present and future business leaders need to embody both.

This course offers a broad, psychological and philosophical perspective on sustainable, moral behaviour in business. How can such behaviour be encouraged in employees, in CEOs, in organizations as a whole, and in their stakeholders? Conversely, how can unsustainable, immoral behaviour be averted? Such questions will be discussed in the context of, among others, normative stakeholder theory, greenwashing, green consumerism, social dilemmas, environmental ethics, and moral development and sustainable values in individuals and organizations.

This course emphasizes linking theory, research and practice, and therefore so do the course assignments. As a first assignment, you and your research team will therefore either (a) carry out a quantitative, applied research project on a topic relevant to sustainability and ethics, or (b) conduct research using CSR-reporting from companies either to identify and provide solutions for moral challenges that these companies are facing or to evaluate the fairness of the criteria used by an NGO that ranks brands on sustainability (depending on whether collaboration with this NGO remains possible). Both assignments will allow you to further apply theory and literature on sustainability and ethics, as well as to subject your own ideas to (empirical) scrutiny, and to communicate your findings concisely, accurately, clearly and straightforwardly in a paper of 2500 words maximum. You and your team will also present your research to your fellow students, allowing you to further practice communicating your ideas.

The second assignment consists of an individual 1000-word essay where you will reflect on material from at least two different lectures. This gives you the opportunity to creatively process the course material. Perhaps you see previously unimagined potential in some of the theories discussed in the lectures, allowing you to propose brand new applications for sustainable development in business. Perhaps you see ways to improve existing theories and make them more relevant to practice. Or perhaps you are skeptical of certain theories, the link between theory and practice, or the value of the empirical research discussed in the lectures.
This course consists of six lectures, two consultation sessions, and one presentation session. Active participation during the lectures may count toward one’s final grade.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: ●    To understand the ways in which sustainability and morality are intertwined.
●    To understand what drives sustainable, moral behaviour in employees, in CEOs, and in organizations as a whole.
●    To become more self-aware of one’s moral development and sustainable values.
●    To translate empirical research and theory on sustainability and business ethics into real-world interventions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: We are being confronted with significant challenges and opportunities from climate change, biodiversity loss, affordable energy and social and economic inequality. Innovation is fundamental in the transformation towards more sustainable markets and society. In this course you will be provided with theory, concepts and methods from innovation economics, entrepreneurship, and environmental and welfare economics literatures in order to critically assess the role of business and her stakeholders (e.g. government, customers, and communities).  We will explore the (im)possibilities of innovating in the context of the sustainability development goals in terms of market failures, overcoming market barrieres, deteminants of eco-innovations and the role of public policies. Insights will be  applied to specific sectors such as clean energy sector.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides insight in the sustainability challenges and the link to finance. The main task of the financial system is to allocate funding to its most productive use. Traditional finance focuses on financial return and regards the financial sector as separate from the society of which it is part and the environment in which it is embedded. By contrast, sustainable finance considers financial, social, and environmental returns in combination and shows how finance can accelerate the transition to a low-carbon, inclusive economy.

The course reviews evidence that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors matter and explains in detail how to incorporate these in company business models and strategies, equity investing, bond investing, and bank lending. The course examines the financial instruments and techniques that can be applied in the context of evolving climate policies (and other sustainability policies). The tools will be applied in a group assignment on the valuation of a company based on ESG factors.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will learn to critically review the externalities embedded in sustainability challenges, to link climate change science with the evolution of financial markets, and to identify the sustainability risks and opportunities for financial professionals. In terms of applications, students will gain knowledge of the main metrics and financial instruments related to sustainability, and of the techniques to measure and manage the exposure of investment and lending portfolios.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87479,2019,Sustainable Strategies,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. FH Wijen', 'H Hanisha', 'SM Musa, MSc', 'YT Wiessner, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Corporate sustainability, inclusive business, corporate (social) responsibility, and shared value creation have been widely embraced by a wide variety of firms. These buzz words basically refer to a firm’s pursuit of social and ecological objectives in addition to the classic economic goals. But what does a strategy to achieve corporate sustainability really look like?

Building on Hambrick and Fredrickson’s (Academy of Management Executive, 2005) well-known article “Are you sure you have a strategy?,” five components of a sustainable strategy will be identified: a sustainability logic (why to go for sustainable business?), sustainability differentiators (how to make a sustainability-related difference?), sustainability vehicles (how to engage a variety of stakeholders?), arenas of sustainable business (in what sustainability markets?), and staging of a sustainable strategy (how to unfold a sustainable strategy over time?).

You will first discover state-of-the-art literature at the interface of corporate strategy and corporate sustainability. Each of the five academic sessions will cover one core strategy component. You will study several relevant articles and make an individual assignment prior to the session. During the classes we will discuss strengths and limitations of the readings, relate each component to other strategy elements, and apply the topic to actual business practices.

Next to the classroom setting, you will conduct fieldwork in a group of students. You will observe a concrete firm that has recently implemented a sustainable strategy. In particular, you will identify a concrete (successful or failed) project—the environmental certification of a particular product, the internationalization of a ‘sustainable product’, development of inclusive business, etc.—and analyze this project using conceptual insights from the academic literature. Drawing on interviews and secondary data, you will comprehensively grasp the essence and details of the project, critically analyze the strengths and limitations of the adopted strategy, and offer constructive suggestions to the focal company to improve their practices. Every group will present the analysis and suggestions during the sixth and final session of the course.
Five academic lectures with individual assignments, field research by groups of students, and group presentations and reports

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • To gain an in-depth theoretical understanding of the components and interrelations of economically, environmentally, and socially sustainable strategies
• To critically evaluate and compare different theories on sustainable strategies
• To chart the ‘real-life’ practices of sustainable business opportunities and threats
• To apply theoretical insights to the actual setting of a firm pursuing a sustainable strategy
• To develop the skills to analyze all factors and actors relevant to an actual sustainable business project

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87442,2019,Sustainable business models,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. RJM van Tulder', 'R Reshef, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Corporate leaders are nowadays searching for new and more innovative value propositions that can be linked to more future looking and crisis resilient business models. In the literature this tendency is also referred to as ‘shared value creation’, ‘social innovation’ or efforts of ‘sustainable leadership’. This course addresses these dimensions from a theoretical as well as practical point of few. One way of considering the question whether business models are actually sustainable is the extent to which they address so called ‘wicked problems’ in society. Wicked problems are those problems that are not only difficult to solve, but even difficult to define. New business models in many sectors are developing that are trying to link up the value proposition of the company to the value gaps of society. Many large firms are doing this, next to the obvious smaller players (social enterprises). We see these new business models appear in such sectors as: care, health, international food, water provision, electricity and the like. How to understand and value these developments? This course also links up with a big NWO-funded programme in the Netherlands in which a number of universities and stakeholders collaborate to bring this theme further. The course thus will also bring you into touch with practitioners and researchers from many different areas. We consider this course also an excellent way of preparing your thesis as follow up on most of the themes of the first semester, but now applied to specific issues of sustainability for which companies have to come up with innovative business models.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: Understanding how company’s ‘value proposition’ are created and implemented in the Netherlands and around the world;
Get the know many version of the CANVAS model: PPP Canvas, etc. which can document and measure more sustainable business models (for instance taking negative and positive externalities into account)
Defining your own leadership potential and checking how leadership is needed for business model innovation
Looking at new business models and the way they can create value and/or solve ‘ wicked’  societal problems
Understanding what the conditions of ‘ social enterprise’  are; how can companies get out of the ‘valley of death’
Studying partnerships as part of sustainable business model innovation around the world; from the perspective of companies, NGOs and governments
Understanding what the business case for ‘shared value creation’?

Support in your Master thesis trajectory; this elective will directly support your master thesis ambitions by linking theory to practice (and hopefully also practical applications) and providing with an opportunity to spend time on your master thesis during the elective.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Rapid development of information technologies (ITs) brings novel opportunities and also imminent challenges in the business world. The business environment is becoming ever more turbulent, which necessitates new rules of strategic thinking in order to gain competitive advantages. Without delving much into the technical details of various omnipresent or emerging ITs, this course attempts to give an overview of the recent significant business trends enabled by development of ITs, which include (and may not be limited to) e-commerce, platformization, big data (and especially the resultant popularity of data-driven artificial intelligence (AI) in business practices). The overall purpose is to train students to learn how to develop a conceptual model of a certain information technology in order to understand and anticipate its implications (including intended benefits and unintended perils) on business practices. Particularly, students will be intentionally directed from a system and mechanism design perspective to contemplate how to best leverage a certain information technology in management. The learning process will be mainly organized in a seminar style, which means students are expected to do intensive pre-class reading and in-class discussion.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of the course students should have a thorough understanding of the following topics:

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87707,2019,System Based Auditing,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['ir. K Wassens', 'J Thoms - van der Heul']",,

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Music moves us physically and emotionally. Even when we don't move, brain areas related to movement are active when we hear music. Yet traditionally, music has by and large been studied from written scores, which can tell us many things. Scores do not, however, tell us how that music actually sounds or makes us feel. Moreover, it lacks the second most important aspect of music: movement. In recent years, developing technologies and blurring borders between scientific fields have paved the way for studying music from the perspective of human movement. Embodied Music Cognition is an exciting young field in musicology, which has as its core premise that movement in all its facets provides a unique window into musical and human behaviour. This course introduces students to many facets of the field, including the origins and purpose(s) of music, neuroscience, digital audio and emotions, and offers 4 weeks of intensive hands-on experience with students running, analysing and writing up their own music research project.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After completing the course students will be able to discuss the link between music (perception) and human movement, especially in terms of evolutionary auditory specialization, in terms of interpersonal coordination and in terms of the effects of musical training on the brain. Students will be able to argue that without movement, there is no music, neither played nor perceived. Students will have had an introduction to several behavioral measurement techniques, digital audio analysis, experiment design, as well as scientific reporting. Finally, students will be able to bridge gaps between research fields in the sense of applying existing research methods and questions to a field that these methods were not developed for.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>De Take-Off is het introductieprogramma voor alle nieuwe  studenten aan Erasmus School of Economics. De Take-Off vindt plaats op maandag 2 september 2019. Tijdens dit introductie evenement maak je kennis met je studie, medestudenten en de faculteit. column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87418,2019,Taxation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Kohlhase'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Taxes affect many business decisions, such as: where to invest, what organizational form to choose, how to finance a business, when and where to recognize revenues and expenses. This is an introductory course providing you with an overview of what taxes exist, to which natural or legal persons they apply, how taxation affects business decisions, and what the fundamentals of domestic and international taxation are.

The course combines financial accounting, tax accounting, and investment principles to answer the question: How do I take tax-optimal business decisions? This knowledge is complemented by information about political developments in the area of taxation. The content from the lecture is applied and deepened during workshops. Guest lectures provide additional insights from practice.

The fundamentals in domestic and international taxation form basic knowledge of auditors, tax advisors, and practitioners in the accounting or tax departments of multinationals. Thus, the course is of interest to those contemplating careers in accounting, consulting, and corporate finance.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students are able to:

column2: Identify different types of taxes levied by governments;
Identify which taxes are relevant for businesses;
Solve tasks where taxes are included in financial planning;
Compare characteristics of corporate taxation vs. taxation of partnerships;
Analyze the impact of taxation on organizational form choices;
Define when profit taxation for businesses and when shareholder level taxes apply;
Give examples on the treatment of tax-loss carryforwards;
Are able to apply double tax agreements;
Are able to apply multilateral agreements in the area of international taxation;
Discuss multiple viewpoints in teams, present and defend joint findings in a report and in front of the class.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Technology evidently enables us to control, organize and optimize the activities and functions of our everyday lives. However, a classical critique in the Philosophy of Technology is that technology also creates a distance between us (as individuals), and the surrounding world. In this regard, the great developments in technology arguably lead to the illusion that everything around us is controllable, rendering us ‘safe’ at a distance. Other approaches focus instead on the mediating and connecting function of technology, which opens up new ways of experiencing and communicating. Some of the questions that motivate this course are: does technology really help us to disclose the world and connect with others, or rather does it alienate us from nature, others and even ourselves?  How is society affected by technology? Are we shaping technology or does technology shape us and our social lives?

To tackle these problems, we first have to ask what do we mean when we talk about ‘technology’. This implies a reflection on the development of technology and its changing meaning, function and role within society; from machines of mass production to virtual communication and the digital realm. This course offers an introduction into the different perspectives on how to understand the relationship between technology and the social lifeworld of human beings; to question, how do technological developments and social changes interact?

We will track the parallel changes of technologies and societies by starting with a historical reflection on the concept of technology and its relation to human nature, from Aristotle, to Bacon, Marx, Engels and Heidegger. On this basis, we will analyse influential approaches in Philosophy of Technology and recent STS like ‘technological determinism’ and ‘social constructivism’. Does technology controls and determines us, or do we socially construct technology instead through our specific needs and actions?
With Latour we will then critically question this antagonism, and explore the idea that we are just a tiny part in a broader network of various non-human and human actors.

We will then engage with (post)phenomenological accounts, who also emphasize the interrelation between humans, society and specific technologies. Instead of describing this interrelation objectively as network, they ask to what extent our subjective experience is mediated, extended  or even limited by technology.
Finally, we will discuss the political and ethical consequences of our interdependence with technology in focusing on the role of algorithms, digital environments and social media.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - To acquire basic knowledge of the concepts and debates (and their development) of the Philosophy of Technology, as well as, key perspectives in recent Science & Technology Studies (STS).
- To describe and analyze technological developments with regard to their relation to social changes.
- To compare and contrast the different kinds of scientific reasoning relevant to the Philosophy of Technology and technological sciences.
- To reflect critically on the assumptions, strengths and limitations of the different perspectives and concepts of technology.
- To apply this knowledge and analyze how technology and society mutually shape each other, with specific focus on the role of digital technologies.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88494,2019,Technology, Policy and Society",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. RFI Moody'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Today’s society is characterized by many as an information society. The industrial society, which was typical for the 19th and the first half of the 20th century, has transformed because of economic and cultural changes into a society in which information and information dissemination are central. The course technology democracy and society focusses on the role of modern ICT  within today’s society and in today’s democracy. The course will elaborate on which societal transformations are set in motion by the use of modern ICT and which consequences these societal transformations can have for the way in which ICT is used and perceived within society. Additionally topics such as chain information between organizations, interplay between technology and democracy and ethical issues will be discussed. In this course the main topics within the public sector related to technology will be addressed, among others, how big and open data influences the policy process, how computerized predictions can impact the way actors make decisions within matters in the public domain such as water management, climate change or safety and security and how this changes the dynamics of power within policy making, also we will address how the role of policy makers and those involved in the public sector changes into an information broker. Subsequently these changes have an effect on society and this effect will also be elaborated on.

De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding / For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After having followed the course, students are able to

column2: • Name which patterns and changes form the basis of today's information society
• Explain how dynamics within the policy process within the public sector change as a result of technology and the emergence of an information society and how this reflects on society
• Explain how public organizations and those employed there change as a result of technological change
• Explain how technology is applied in organizations and cooperation between organizations
• Name and reflect on ethical dilemmas regarding the use of technology

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87200,2019,Television Audiences,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. JC van Sterkenburg'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Central in this course are the television audience and audience reception research. We will explore how television audiences interpret and receive popular television genres and ‘texts’. We will pay attention, amongst other things, to the role played by social dimensions like race, ethnicity, gender, (dis)ability, social class, religion, in audience receptions. Television can be considered a powerful source for giving meaning to these social dimensions but different viewers can negotiate and interpret these meanings in different ways.  Various forms of qualitative data-collection and –  analysis will be discussed in order to prepare students to do independent research into television audiences.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The interaction between media representations and audience receptions
• Audience reception research, with a specific focus on popular television genres and social dimensions such as gender, race, ethnicity, religion
• The different components of qualitative audience-related research and how these components relate to each other
• Conduct qualitative audience research into TV audiences both individually and in teams
• Reflect critically on methodological and theoretical articles in the field
• Apply practical skills required for qualitative audience research, e.g. drafting a topic list, interviewing, qualitative data-analysis, presenting findings

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Even as mobile internet access continues to expand, television remains the most popular global medium as viewers watched an average of 167 minutes per day in 2019. In light of this continuing popularity, this course explores the complex relations between television and modern societies. This course uses a variety of interdisciplinary paradigms to understand television in its historical and social contexts. Course readings and seminars address three interrelated topics: theoretical approaches to television, the social dynamics of audience reception, and cultural politics of television content.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will have gained knowledge and understanding of:
•             Theoretical approaches and key concepts related to television.
•             Perspectives on television at the level of industry, audience, and text.
•             Analyze and explain television in a variety of historical and social contexts.
•             Reflect critically on the mainstream and academic discourses surrounding television

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Het practicum dient als een eerste kennismaking met het observeren en testen van kinderen. Tijdens het practicum zullen een aantal psychometrische basisbegrippen aan de orde komen evenals hoe individuele verschillen te meten zijn.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:

column5: afname, scoring en interpretatie uit te voeren van enkele intelligentietests en sociale competentietests voor kinderen met de ethische kwesties die daarbij in acht genomen moeten worden (eindtermen 10, 13 en 14);
een professioneel terugkoppelingsgesprek uit te voeren (eindtermen 16 en 17);
een professioneel, samenhangend en helder testrapport met de geëigende structuurindeling te schrijven (eindtermen 15 en 16);
te reflecteren op de eigen competenties, feedback te vragen en te ontvangen (eindtermen 18 en 19).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85744,2019,Testvaardigheden IV,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['drs. JTM Rosbach'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Dit practicum bouwt voort op practicum 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 2.1 en 2.6, waarin studenten hebben geoefend met ontwikkelingspsychologische en neuropsychologische testafname en de schriftelijke en mondelinge rapportage van testresultaten. In dit practicum maken studenten kennis met testmaterialen die zijn ontwikkeld om cognitieve capaciteiten in kaart te brengen en schoolse vaardigheden te meten. Studenten zullen een ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek bij een typisch ontwikkelend kind afnemen. De testafname zal plaatsvinden in de thuissituatie van het kind waar aan de hand van gestandaardiseerde instrumenten de cognitieve capaciteiten en taalontwikkeling onderzocht zal worden. Daarnaast zal ook de opvoedingsomgeving in kaart worden gebracht, waardoor de scores op intelligentie en taalontwikkeling in de bredere opvoedingscontext van het kind kunnen worden geïnterpreteerd.

Een ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek bestaat veelal uit meerdere tests over verschillende ontwikkelingsdomeinen om op die manier voldoende informatie te verzamelen en goed zicht te krijgen op de aangemelde problematiek. Door in het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek zowel eventuele leerproblemen, als gedragsproblemen en cognitieve vaardigheden in kaart te brengen, wordt een volledig beeld gevormd van de sterktes en zwaktes van het kind en kunnen verklaringen gevonden worden voor eventuele leerachterstanden op school. Ook de opvoedingsomgeving (denk aan: gezinsstructuur, ouderfactoren en leefomgeving) en de sociaal-emotionele ontwikkeling van het kind kunnen een rol spelen in de cognitieve en gedragsontwikkeling van het kind. Daarom wordt in dit practicum een variatie aan tests en vragenlijsten behandeld die kunnen worden gebruikt in het diagnostisch proces en in gezinspedagogisch onderzoek.

Veel van het materiaal dat wordt gebruikt in het practicum is gelieerd aan de praktijk. Zo worden bijvoorbeeld de Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC) en de Taaltoets alle Kinderen (TAK) behandeld die door orthopedagogen tijdens de diagnostiek van onder andere ontwikkelingsstoornissen en leerstoornissen worden gebruikt. De gemeten cognitieve capaciteiten worden doorgaans in het bredere kader van o.a. schoolprestaties geïnterpreteerd door bijvoorbeeld ook gebruik te maken van (andere) CITO toetsen. Hiertoe wordt een verplicht practicumcollege gegeven dat zal ingaan op het CITO leerlingvolgsysteem op school. Daarnaast wordt de ontwikkeling van het kind in de complexe werkelijkheid onderzocht door kennis te maken met een instrument die de opvoedingsomgeving van het kind in kaart brengt. Hiermee wordt de link van praktijk naar pedagogisch wetenschappelijk onderzoek gemaakt. De vaardigheden die de student opdoet in dit practicum kunnen worden toegepast in een praktijkstage of onderzoeksstage in de bachelorfase en masterfase.

Naast het oefenen met het afnemen van het testmateriaal, zal de student de verkregen gegevens verwerken in een testrapportage en oefenen met het terugkoppelen van testresultaten aan een fictieve ouder. De testafname en het oudergesprek worden geëvalueerd in een zelfreflectieverslag.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • een uitgebreid ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek af te nemen bij een kind (eindtermen 5 en 10);
• de opvoedingsomgeving van het kind te observeren en te coderen met behulp van gestandaardiseerde, gevalideerde instrumenten (eindtermen 5 en 10);
• bevindingen uit het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek op een praktijkgerichte manier te beschrijven;
• bevindingen uit het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek terug te koppelen aan een ouder;
• peerfeedback te geven en ontvangen en op basis hiervan eigen werk kritisch te beschouwen en te verbeteren (eindtermen 18 en 19);
• en zonder instructie en met enige begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):
• een samenhangende en heldere tekst te schrijven (eindterm 15);
• een professionele schrijfstijl toe te passen (eindtermen 15 en 16);
• een testrapport met de geëigende structuurindeling te schrijven (eindtermen 15 en 16).

column1: In an age where customer opinion and feedback can have an immediate, major effect upon the success of a business or organization, marketers must have the ability to analyze unstructured data in everything from social media and internet reviews to customer surveys or phone logs. This course provides students with tools that enable them to effectively implement and use text analytics in a marketing context. In the course the complete analysis process, from data input, summarizing and visualizing and more rigorous statistical analysis, will be covered.
Next to the weekly lectures, students will make a group assignment to gain hands on experience with the techniques from the course.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87070,2019,Text and Context: From Source to Science,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. CLA Willemse', ""LC in 't Veld""]",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this methodological course we will focus on analyzing primary sources. As the experiences and ideas of ordinary people are sporadically documented, historians use ego-documents, such as letters, diaries and oral sources as one, and sometimes even the only, way to capture this 'view from below'. In the first part of the course students read and discuss literature on important debates concerning the use of primary sources such as biographies, letters, travel literature, songs, and visuals etc. in historical research; debates on the problematic notion of identity; and debates on notions such as discourse, focalization and argumentation as tools of narrative analysis, as well as on self-reflexivity. These notions are crucial to the application of narrative analysis as used in the course and are based on recent theoretical developments within history, anthropology, and cultural, minority, and subaltern studies. The emphasis in the second part of the course is on practicing con/text analysis on primary sources related to the master thesis of the participants in the course. This serves to understand better the relation between primary sources, the methodological and theoretical framework used, and the analytical findings in historical research.

In the first part of the course the literature is read individually and the assignments are discussed in sub-groups in class. In these first weeks participants will also record an oral source or access an ego-document or another primary source related to the subject of their master’s thesis. In the second part of the course the participants will discuss and practice the methodology of con/text analysis with respect to their own primary sources.. At the end of the course each participant writes a final essay in which he or she reports on the theoretical as well as practical aspects of analyzing his or her own primary source ‘against the grain’.
Note: Students who have successfully completed ""Narrative Analysis, Orality, and Biography"" (CH4107) in previous years can not register for this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students can comprehend and discuss literature on, and discern the various ways in which narrative and visual sources can be used in historical research
• Students are able to read and analyze primary source material - oral or written, visual or auditory – ‘against the grain’ and report about this in both oral and written reports

• Students can argue, both orally and written, the relevance of discourses, contexts, identities and silences for narrative analysis in general, and for understanding their own primary sources in particular in relation to the main research question of their Master’s Thesis

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: When studying art and culture, film is one cultural discipline that demands our attention. In all its diversity, film is an extremely popular art form. It constitutes a major industry and its stories, characters, and taglines have found their way into mainstream culture. In this course, we explore the art of filmmaking from various academic perspectives. We discuss the historical development of cinema as an entertainment industry as well as film as an art product. We learn to use and read film grammar and analyse filmic content. We discuss major topics in film criticism and film theory. Finally, we consider the reception and effect of films within their social, cultural, and political contexts.
Attending the weekly lectures is strongly advised, but not mandatory. Please make sure you arrive on time.
The aims of the lectures are multifold:
- To sketch the broad outlines of the weekly course subjects, thereby largely following the outlines of the provided literature;
- To investigate selected key aspects of the course subjects deeper, mainly by means of case studies on specific films and excerpts from the contemporaneous writings;
- To illustrate the course subjects and the case-studies by means of clips from movies and documentaries;
- To learn and practice the analysis of the moving image and its meaning-making mechanisms;
- To learn film grammar through key concepts introduced every week in relation to the topic of the lecture;
- To acquire a critical approach to the established narratives of cinema culture and history.
The lecture slides will be published on Canvas after the lecture.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students gain insight into film history, film presentation, film production techniques, world cinema industries, film grammar, methods of film analysis and key concepts in film theory. They learn to consider this popular art form from different academic perspectives.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89861,2019,The Avant-Garde: Experimental Art, Photography and Film",Engels,Erasmus University College,,"['CJG Somzé, MA', 'T de Groot, MPhil']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Avant-Garde is the French military term for front-guard and is generally used to describe the most adventurous manifestations of modern art, photography and film. Art – in the broadest sense of the word - that forges ahead, breaks down barriers and challenges the status quo, but at the same time, art that is difficult, sometimes incomprehensible and elitist. Through a combination of the humanities and sociological perspectives, we will trace the roots of the Avant-Garde, examine the challenges that avant-garde artists faced and discuss whether avant-garde art is still possible today.

The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between the visual arts and society from – roughly - 1850 to the present. Students will become familiar with the most influential visions on avant-garde art, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art. Students will be able to think, write and talk about avant-garde art in its historical and social context; research appropriate literature; and create self-formulated questions.

All this will lead up to a symposium that we will organise at the end of the course, during which students will present and discuss short papers about the several themes that we discussed during our lectures and museum visits.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between the visual arts and society for approximately the last 150 years. Students will become familiar with the most influential visions on avant-garde art, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art. Students will be able to think, write and talk about avant-garde art in its historical and social context; research appropriate literature; and create self-formulated questions.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85647,2019,The Brain,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. L Gootjes'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The brain: maybe the most important organ of our body. Without the brain we would not be aware of anything around us. The world would not exist for us. It’s not our eyes that make us see, it’s not our ears that make us hear. It is only in our brain were we become aware of what we see and what we hear. In this course you will learn about this exciting organ, the brain, with its neural circuits giving rise to psychological functions like cognition and emotion.

Everything that happens in the brain is the result of interactions between brain cells, the neurons. Neurons communicate with each other through chemical substances. In this block you will learn how this communication takes place and what happens when this communication goes wrong in clinical disorders like depression and schizophrenia. You will also learn how the brain develops, how neural circuits arise and how these are subject to modifications as a result of experience.

Brain research is constantly giving us new ideas about how the brain works and what happens when things seem to go wrong in the brain. There are still many things that we (or better ‘science’) do not exactly know about the brain. This makes it a very exciting topic to study. If everything would be known already, it would be less fun. Actually, some say that we might never be able to understand the brain completely. As L. Watson, a well-known scientist, said:
”If the brain were so simple we could understand it, we would be so simple we couldn't.”

Indeed, brain is a comprehensive subject.  You will learn a lot of new names and terms and this might be a little confusing in the beginning. When you feel like this, just think of the following quote from another scientist, W. Rogers:
“You know you've got to exercise your brain just like your muscles"".</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of this course, you will have a deeper understanding of

column2: •          the cellular basis of brain functioning and neural circuits (including the role and working of neurotransmitters and receptors, and the cascade that the binding of a neurotransmitter to a receptor sets off).
•          how neural circuits arise in the development of the brain.
•          how modifications of neural circuits take place as a result of experience and learning
•         the biological basis of brain dysfunctions (e.g. psychiatric disorders) and the working of psychotropic drugs
•         the process of recovery after brain damage, involving neuroplasticity

column1: The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master's thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, whereafter students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:

discussion of and information on possible research methods
discussion of case studies and other work in progress
discussion of case studies and other work in progress

column1: The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .

Thomas McCraw, in his 2007 biography on the American-Austrian scholar Schumpeter, called him the prophet of innovation and one of the world’s greatest ever economists. This is not to say that Schumpeter was immediately recognised as such in the 1930s and 1940s when he worked at Harvard University. Indeed, it was only during the IT revolution in the 1980s and 1990s that economists began to take note of Schumpeter’s change- and innovation-oriented historical approach to economics. The historical part, however, economists tended to forget. Schumpeter moved from Vienna to Harvard in 1932 to continue his work on the role of entrepreneurship and innovation as the main drivers of capitalism. He was influenced by the Historical School of Economics, including the works of Gustav von Schmoller and Werner Sombart. The notion of creative destruction made him famous, but the idea had previously entered the social sciences through Friedrich Nietzsche and was used for the first time in economics by Werner Sombart. The roots of the concept may be traced as far back as Indian philosophy. This course looks at innovations within large and small firms and networks across a range of industries from IT to food and fashion. It explores the role of institutions and organizations, in particular governments or similar gatekeeping structures, and the diversity of innovation processes and across different sectors of the economy in the long twentieth century. Finally, it focuses on the effects of innovation on economic growth, international competitiveness, and employment. Different theoretical approaches emphasising cultural, national, regional, local, and firm-based factors, will be explored and applied to case studies selected by the students.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

• Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
• Students can analyse, report and present their research findings

• Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87119,2019,The Business of Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The media sector is an important economic industry that is increasingly expanding into other sectors such as healthcare or connected vehicles. During this course we focus  on the  media  firm as  our unit of analysis  and we will use the  business  model canvas  as  our main   analytical model.

During the classes we will discuss how media firms design value  propositions, engage with customers, produce content and services (value chains), manage their organizations and generate revenues. We will address the impact of new (digital) media technologies on the business models of media firms. Furthermore, we will also look at specific business related issues that media firms face in specific sectors, such as TV, gaming and digital video. We will also address how government policy impacts business models of media firms, for instance around copyrights, privacy and competition law.

An important part of this course consists of guest lectures by people that work in media companies. These guest lecturers will familiarize students with real life experiences around the topics that will be discussed.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 60. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Theoretical approaches, key concepts and current developments in the field of media business and media management;
• The operations of contemporary media organizations from a management and business perspective;
• Read, critique, and apply relevant theoretical concepts to specific business related issues faced by media firms
• Analyze and critically reflect upon the use of business models by media firms

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86999,2019,The Changing Social and Economic position of the Arts in Society: A combined economic, sociological and historic approac",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. J Roscam Abbing'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Firstly, the course provides insight into the different ways economists and sociologists analyse phenomena in the arts and whether these approaches can or cannot supplement one another. Secondly the course looks at broad developments in the arts from both a sociological and an economic perspective.

In the 19th century there has been a process of transition in the arts. Part of the arts became serious and less commercial when non-profits were established. Over the last 50 years again there has been a far-reaching process of transition. The latter will be the main topic of the course.

We will examine the changes during this period in the social and economic position of the established as well as popular arts taking into account longer term developments. Together we will attempt to answer several questions: How did the established arts become so serious? Is this presently changing? Have artists lost their monopoly on creativity and authenticity? Is there less respect for art? Why is the value of authorship still high in the arts? Why was the rejection of commercial behaviour and the pursuit of profit so strong? How to explain and interpret the present re-commercialization in the arts? And why are artists still not allowed to “compromise”, even though the taboo on marketing and cultural entrepreneurship has largely disappeared? Why are artists still prepared to work for very low incomes? Are artists exploited by non-profits? And so forth. (Because most participants are likely to be involved in the arts, we can learn from one another. Therefore discussions will be important in the seminar.)

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students learn about the transitions in the arts that have taken place in the past 50 years and how (the absence of) transitions can be explained. They learn which historical developments are important for a proper understanding of the present state of the arts, and why these developments are not only social, cultural or economic. Among other things, they learn about the effects on art worlds and artists of the present re-commercialization in the arts and the fading of some boundaries between the established and popular arts, as well as about the reactions they cause among artists, art organizations and in society.

Those students who are familiar with the tools of the sociologist learn that these can fruitfully be combined with the tools economists use, and vice versa. Both groups learn about the possibilities but also the limitations of each other’s tools.</body>

CDC van der Veeke', 'dr. I van Oorschot', 'dr. JF van Houdt', 'dr. JP Kloeg', 'dr. MJ Kruithof', 'dr. R van den Akker', 'dr. VFC Servant - Miklos', 'JI Wildschut', 'S Koevoets', 'S van Balen', 'T de Groot, MPhil', 'WM van Baalen, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: There is consensus among scientists in fields that are contributing to the study of climate change that mankind has a negative impact on our climate and that we are rapidly running out of time to avert a catastrophically changed climate. Still we – mankind, as a whole - do not seem to be in a hurry to change the ways in which we have organised our everyday lives, our economies and our societies. Why? And what is to be done?

In this course we discuss the ways in which we shape the climate and the climate has shaped, and will continue to shape, us – from the very distant past to the not so distant future. By combining perspectives from philosophical anthropology, political economy and (geo)politics students get a thorough introduction in the problematic of climate change. Throughout the course we pay particular attention to the concept of the Anthropocene as well as its uses and abuses in popular discourse and academic disciplines as varied as climate sciences, geology, social sciences or the humanities.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Have a basic understanding of the causes and consequences of Climate Change;
• Have a basic understanding of the debate about the (use and abuse of the term) Anthropocene;
• Have a basic understanding of economic solutions to climate change;
• Have a basic understanding of the politics of climate change;
• Have a basic understanding of the pros and cons of technological fixes;
• Have a basic understanding of the SF mode in both its literary and theoretical sense;
• Have an advanced understanding of the work of key thinkers on Climate Change such as Latour and Haraway, Moore and Giddens and Morton and Jonas.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The main objective of this course is to familiarize students with key concepts and major perspectives – developments, trends, and problems – in the economics of art and culture. The course will present the cultural economic perspective as developed by David Throsby, Bruno Frey, Arjo Klamer and other economic sociologists and contrast this with the standard economic approach to the arts and culture. The central question is how artists, consumers and cultural organizations realize the social and cultural values of art and culture. Another central theme is how cultural goods are priced and valued in the economy, within society, and within the art world. Special attention will be given to the role of digital technology in the process of valuation and pricing of the arts and culture. During the lectures these issues will be discussed from a theoretical perspective, while the workgroups will focus on the application of these theories to concrete economic phenomena or from the world of arts and culture that are familiar to students from their everyday life.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The goal of this course is to familiarize students with what has come to be called the cultural economic perspective. After this course students should be able to identify the differences between this perspective and the standard economic perspective, and they are expected to be able to analyze various phenomena using the cultural economic perspective.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89714,2019,The Economics of Climate Change (TI Economics Lectures 2020),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89626,2019,The High Enlightenment I,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. L van Bunge'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

By 1750s the French Enlightenment in particular takes off its gloves. Diderot and D’Holbach start propagating a ‘Spinozist’ materialism, which raises the issue of the origins of the Radical Enlightenment. Simultaneously Rousseau singlehandedly revolutionizes French political thought. Meanwhile, the German Enlightenment (Thomasius, Wolff, Lessing) gets under way and the eighteenth-century culture of sensibility spreads throughout Europe. Following the French Revolution, Burke and De Maistre launch their Counter-Enlightenment, the echoes of which can still be traced in twentieth-century critical accounts of the Enlightenment such as Adorno and Horkheimer’s Dialectics of Enlightenment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.

Having completed this course, students will be familiar with some of the main ideas put forward by D’Holbach and the so-called ‘radical Enlightenment’. They will understand the main characteristics of Rousseau’s thought. They will be able to distinguish some of the key differences between the French and the German Enlightenment. They will know some of the most important critical assessments of the Enlightenment, put forward during the late eighteenth and the twentieth centuries.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89627,2019,The High Enlightenment II: Kant,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. P Schuurman'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: David Hume’s criticism of the notion of causality prompted Immanuel Kant to develop a new philosophy in which causality is no longer a property of the world outside us, but rather a concept in our minds that assists us in making sense of the world. This is his famous ‘Copernican Revolution’; rather than objects in the world shaping the cognitive operations of subjects (epistemological realism), these subjective operations determine our perceptions of objects and our judgements about objects (epistemological idealism). This is only part of Kant’s enormous contribution to philosophy. In his ethics he defended morality in the form of a law that demands to be obeyed for its own sake, the commands of which are not issued by some alien authority but the voice of reason that the moral subject can recognize as his own.

Finally, although Kant was a great Enlightened demolisher of the truth of metaphysics, he nevertheless maintained that certain notions can still have a useful regulative function; one example is the notion of teleology. This notion plays a major role in his philosophy of history, his political philosophy and his radical plea for world peace, Perpetual Peace (1795); paradoxically enough, this teleological perspective also implies a surprisingly positive evaluation of the function of war.

Fulltime students can skip one session without any apology to the teacher. (Reserve this option for calamities.) For each additional session, please do not feel obliged to apologise either, but hand in an additional mini-essay. The mini-essay should start with a thesis or question that is clearly related to the prescribed literature, followed by a short argumentation that is used to defend the thesis or answer the question. The mini-essay will be marked. The mark for the mini-essay replaces the result for the highest marked question of the eight questions of the examination. For the document of the mini-essay please use the extensions .doc .docx or .rtf. For the name of your mini-essay please use the following format: <number of the week of the assignment><number expressing the total number of assignment you have completed so far> <Family name> <First name>, e.g. 0302 Schuurman Paul. For the mini-essay itself: provide your name on top; give the title, followed by the essay itself; conclude with the number of words of the essay. Use a line spacing of one with a Palatino Linotype 12 point letter, and try to write your mini-essay on one single A4.

RBC Huijsmans', 'E Papyrakis', 'prof.dr. M Arsel', 'prof.dr. P Knorringa', 'prof.dr. RA Icaza Garza', 'prof.dr. W Harcourt', 'prof.mr.dr. CJM Arts']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is a critical introduction to theories and strategies of international development – looking at the making, unmaking and remaking of development from cultural, historical, and political economic perspectives. It aims building a dialogue between the students’ own experiences and knowledges of development with the different approaches of the course literature from development studies and beyond. The three modules focus on: narratives of economic development; people and places in development; and post development and alternatives to development. Emphasis will be on the analyses of development as a historical process, an aspiration, a discourse of power and set of practices and in engaging students in critical approaches to development as a study and as a practice. The course fosters an open learning environment using participatory interactive methodology in order to encourage co-learning knowledge generation. The course features interactive lectures, a group produced video essay and student-led workshops.
Cornwall, A. and D. Eade, eds. (2010) Deconstructing Development Discourse: Buzzwords and Fuzzwords. Warwickshire: Practical Action Publishing.
Escobar, A. (1995) Encountering Development. Princeton: Princeton University Press.
McKinnon, K.(2011) Development Professionals in Northern Thailand: Hope, Politics and Power. Singapore, ASAA Southeast Asia Publications Series, Singapore University Press.
Mosse, D. (2005). Cultivating Development: An ethnography of aid policy and practice. London, Ann Arbor (MI): Pluto Press.
Oyeronke, O. (1997) The Invention of Women. Making an African Sense of Western Gender Discourses. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press.
Rist, G. (2003) The History of Development: From Western Origins to Global Faith. London: Zed Books.
Sachs, W. (1992/2010) The Development Dictionary: a guide to knowledge as power. London: Zed Books.
Sen, A. (1999) Development as Freedom. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
De Sousa Santos, B. Epistemologies of the South. Justice Against Epistemicide. Boulder: Paradigm Publishers/

This course can only be taken as part of the LDE programme track ‘Migration and Development’
During the course the students will acquire a critical lens through which to analyze development by being able to:
a) Unpack development as a contested set of cultural, political, economic and historical processes and relations
b) Appraise how ‘development problems’ and ‘solutions’ are understood according to different conceptual approaches to development
c) Reflect critically on their own understanding of and encounters with development
d) Work collaboratively within a multidisciplinary and multicultural context to communicate ideas about the making of development visually, orally and in writing.
e) Engage in a critical dialogue on development studies with peers and staff

column1: What shall we do? How shall we interact? What is (the) good? These fundamental normative questions are inseparable from the question: Who are we? Moral philosophy does not develop abstract theories of agency, morality and the Good

In this course we will discuss about normative consequences of different conceptions of the subject of morality in different accounts of moral philosophy. We will distinguish between different concepts of the moral agent and different understandings of personal practical identity, integrate current findings of moral psychology, and confront traditional ideals of the moral self with future visions of trans- or posthuman subjects. Finally, we will ask in how far the self-understanding of human beings necessarily implies the idea of a moral self.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

- You will be able to distinguish between different conceptions and ideals of the moral self and to understand how they have developed in the course of history and how they are used in current debates.

- You will be able to distinguish between different concepts of the moral agent as well as between different theories of personal practical identity, to discuss their normative implications and to articulate your own philosophical position with respect to the moral self.

- On this this footing you will be enabled to put ideas and ideals of the moral self into a broader context of human self-understanding and to critically discuss how they may have to be modified in view of future prospects and challenges.</body>

column1: This course examines practical and theoretical issues concerning European Integration and touches upon legal and economic implications of the European Union: What is the political background of European Integration? How does it affect us in daily life? Is it possible to preserve a country’s specificities, like culture or social security, while at the same time benefitting from more economic exchange?

column2: • A trip to Brussels to visit the European institutions and meet EU decision makers
• Lecturers with different backgrounds of expertise in European matters
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Getting a principal understanding of economic integration. This implies a basic understanding of international trade and federalism. But also the interrelation between the political process and economic integration will be discussed.

• The historical and legal background of European integration will be presented. The students will be acquainted with the constitutional principles of the EU as well as specific sector policies (e.g. competition policy and agricultural policy).
• From the viewpoint of their own academic background and experience, the students shall write a short term paper on a European integration issue.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89558,2019,The Politics of Skepticism,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. TKAM de Mey', 'prof.dr. L van Bunge']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The first half of the course introduces by means of online lectures the different kinds of skepticism and the main ideas of both the skeptics and their critics. In the subsequent seminars, the students critically discuss draft papers in which the relations are explored and investigated systematically  between skepticism on the one hand, and, on the other hand, contemporary political ideas and debates, such as toleration, relativism, fundamentalism, the roles of prejudices and populism,

The second part of the course has a historical focus. For a wide variety of reasons during the sixteenth century Pyrrhonism enjoyed a remarkable comeback. Some experts would have it that modern Theory of Knowledge actually emerged from the sustained attempt to overcome the challenge of Pyrrhonism. In this course we will also address the moral and political ramifications of the spectre of skepticism: it would seem that early modern theories of religious toleration crucially depended on some variety of skepticism, while natural law theories were invoked in order to argue in favour of objective moral truths, and to silence the Pyrrhonists once and for all.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: (1) the student is able to pinpoint and to explain systematically the relations between metaphysical, epistemological and conceptual skepticism on the one hand, and political ideas and debates on the other hand
(2) the student is able to pinpoint and to explain historically the relations between skeptics and skeptical traditions on the one hand, and political ideas and debates on the other hand
(3) the student is able to define and address, either systematically or historically, a problem of his or her own choice, relating to both skepticism and politics</body>

column1: This course presents a concise overview of financial markets. This includes coverage of a wide array of financial assets, the risks associated with their use, various trading mechanisms employed by exchanges and different forms of organization that govern the interaction among market participants. This will provide students with a solid foundation for understanding the continually evolving financial system, its institutions, its markets, and its products.

We start with an overview of the financial system and talk about the functions of financial markets and institutions. We describe the financial institutions industry and pay special attention to the mutual fund industry. We cover the basic features of (1) the money markets (2) the bond market (3) the stock market (4) the mortgage markets (5) the foreign exchange market and (6) cryptocurrencies. We touch upon valuation of different financial assets, risk assessment, behavior of the financial asset users and implications of the financial market on the economy as a whole.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Apply theories to explain and predict changes in valuation of various financial products.

column1: <body>This course teaches students how they can use their academic skills and knowledge in society. Historians have specific skills which enables them to contribute to public debates or which are useful in professional contexts. Politicians and policy advisors realize more and more that knowledge about the past can be important to understand the contemporary world. Governments use the past to shape collective identities and to strengthen social cohesion. History education is often used to promote active citizenship, but historical museums and television series are also mobilized to create shared identities. Historians use a conceptual framework to assess the impact of the past on contemporary developments and to make useful historical comparisons. They are also capable to qualify and deepen the use of the past in popular culture, such as the heritage and the entertainment industry.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course has four main objectives. Firstly, students can communicate scientific knowledge to a broad public. This implies that they are capable to bridge the gap between academic ethics and concrete expectations from consumers. Students are also able to analyze societal challenges from a contemporary and historical perspective. Finally, students can evaluate different forms of public history and they can communicate their assessment in oral and written reports.</body>
