<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit vak wordt stilgestaan bij de kernproblemen van de sociologische theorie. We doen dat door voort te bouwen op het B1-vak Geschiedenis van de Sociologie. Aan bod komen onder meer de perspectieven van Erving Goffman, Jürgen Habermas, Pierre Bourdieu, Michel Foucault, Niklas Luhmann, Bruno Latour, Judith Butler en Cedric Robinson. Centraal staan de theoretische problemen van de verhouding tussen individu en sociaal collectief, en tussen samenleving en natuur. We zullen zien hoe met die problemen op heel fundamenteel verschillende manieren is omgegaan.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Inzicht in het theoretische probleem van de verhouding tussen individu en sociaal collectief;
• Vaardigheid opdoen met het schrijven van een boekbespreking (zoals in een tijdschrift).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88236,2019,Theoretische criminologie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['drs. E Jaspers', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen', 'SD Kruit, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Theoretische criminologie beoogt inzicht te bieden in 1) de wetenschapstheoretische uitgangspunten van de criminologie, 2) de verschillende verklaringen van criminaliteit en van sociale reacties, en 3) de mogelijkheden om verschillende theorieën toe te passen op drie probleemgebieden (geweld, fraude & drugs) en te integreren. Door zowel recente als vroegere inzichten aan bod te laten komen wordt een beeld gegeven van de ontwikkeling van de criminologie als wetenschap, en hoe deze door maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen wordt beïnvloed.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• verschillen en overeenkomsten aangeven tussen de verschillende theoretische stromingen in termen van onderzoeksvragen, verklaringen, assumpties en niveaus van verklaring;
• de inhoud van de belangrijkste criminologische verklaringen kennen en toepassen op concrete (kennis)problemen en delicten;
• op basis van informatie over onderzoeksbevindingen conclusies trekken over de empirische houdbaarheid van theorieën;
• aangeven op welke manier maatschappelijke condities het bijeenbrengen en toepassen van wetenschappelijke kennis over criminaliteit en crimineel gedrag kunnen beïnvloeden.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87854,2019,Theorie en geschiedenis van het hedendaagse strafrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. CL van der Vis', 'mr. S Salverda', 'prof.mr. J uit Beijerse']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De huidige regeling van het straf- en strafprocesrecht is de resultante van een geschiedenis van ideeën, systeemtheoretische opvattingen en wettelijke regelingen, in relatie met meer feitelijke (maatschappelijke) ontwikkelingen. In dit vak worden voor diverse belangrijke kenmerken en leerstukken van het geldende straf- en strafprocesrecht de grondslagen nagegaan. Hiermee vormt het vak de theoretische en historische achtergrond voor drie grote, en grotendeels positiefrechtelijk georiënteerde, verplichte vakken in de mastervariant: Onderzoekspracticum verdiepend formeel strafrecht, Verdiepend materieel strafrecht en Sanctierecht. De positiefrechtelijke stand van zaken is immers niet enkel een gegeven, maar als vanzelfsprekend ook een – mogelijk vanuit actueel perspectief betwistbare – uitkomst van historische discussies of keuzes. Deze benadering levert handvatten voor kritische analyse op, die van essentieel belang zijn voor een niet alleen op de praktijk maar ook op wetenschap gerichte opleiding in het strafrecht.

Het vak is opgebouwd aan de hand van capita selecta uit de drie genoemde deelgebieden. De verschillende onderwerpen worden daarbij, waar aangewezen tevens zoveel mogelijk in chronologische volgorde behandeld. Zo worden er vragen behandeld als: Wat is het rechtskarakter van het straf(proces)recht? Waarom heeft ons strafproces zich sinds het Romeinse forum als inquisitoir ontwikkeld? Waarom is niet elk ongewenst gedrag strafbaar en welk ongewenst gedrag eigenlijk wel? Wat leren ons discussies uit de totstandkomingsgeschiedenis van de Wetboeken van Strafrecht en Strafvordering voor een goed begrip van actuele thema’s als de plaats van de raadsman bij het politieverhoor? Waarom wordt op misdaad eigenlijk met straf gereageerd en waarom met het specifieke sanctie-arsenaal dat wij hebben?

Het vak bouwt mede voort op bacheloronderwijs in de rechtstheorie en -geschiedenis en behandelt met name de specifiek strafrechtstheoretische ontwikkeling, waarbij veel aandacht zal worden besteed aan de stromingen die het huidige strafrecht en strafrechtelijk debat (nog steeds) kleuren. Bij verschillende onderdelen zal ook een rechtsvergelijkend perspectief (nationaal en internationaal) worden geboden, zodat duidelijk wordt waarin en waarom andere rechtsstelsels thans verschillen, als gevolg van een andere theoretische- en historische ontwikkeling.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De grondslagen en kenmerken van het geldende strafprocesrecht, materiële strafrecht en sanctierecht verklaren vanuit hun theoretische en historische ontwikkeling;
• Belangrijke verschillen in grondslagen en ontwikkeling met andere rechtsstelsels, zowel nationaal als internationaal, doorgronden;
• Samenwerken in het voorbereiden en verzorgen van een presentatie ten aanzien van de theoretische en historische grondslagen van een strafrechtelijk of maatschappelijk vraagstuk;
• Een kritische visie vormen op de maatschappelijke rol van het strafrecht aan de hand van diens theoretische en historische ontwikkeling en bijbehorende ethische perspectieven.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86954,2019,Theories of the Avant-Gardes,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. N van Poecke'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Avant-garde is the French military term for “front-guard” and is generally used to describe the most adventurous manifestations of modern art. Art that forges ahead, that is innovative, breaks down barriers and challenges the status quo; but at the same time, art that is difficult, sometimes incomprehensible and elitist. Through a combination of the humanities and sociological  perspectives, we will trace the roots of the Western avant-garde, examine the challenges that avant- garde artists faced (and still face today) and discuss whether avant-garde art is still possible in contemporary modernity and if so, in what kind of manifestations. As this course is a seminar, students are responsible for much of the course’s discussions. Students will contribute to the course by being responsible for examination of the assigned literature and presentation of case studies that serve as exemplars. In this way, the class is research and communication intensive, relying on student interests to direct the exploration of the course's main themes. The course is entirely in English, requires class participation and presentation, individual and group work, and extensive and creative written work.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between changes in the (visual) arts and popular culture, on the one hand, and changes in society, on the other, for approximately the last 200 years. Students will become familiar with some of the most influential theories of the avant-garde, some of the most influential criticisms and critics of avant-garde art, and some of the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art – from Duchamp’s urinal to Barnett Newman’s abstract paintings, and from Manet to David Foster Wallace. Students will be able to think, read, write and talk about avant-garde art in its socio-historical and aesthetical context; research appropriate literature; create self-formulated questions, and to make an avant-garde art work themselves.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87788,2019,Theories on Change, on Behaviour and on Differences",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MS Kaandorp', 'GCA Manchia', 'prof.dr. GWJ Hendrikse', 'prof.dr. SR Giessner']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The main objective of this second course is to deepen insights into actual change situations – taking into account not only the organization itself, but also the social, political and cultural context in which changes occur. Change can here relate to strategic changes, which tend to be planned), but also to unplanned changes, which need to be managed.

We will do this by reading (about) and using post-modern and social constructionist change theory, methods and concepts. Building on and extending previously acquired knowledge on organisational development and change, the course helps students: 1) to acquire the relevant conceptual and methodological foundation and 2) to develop the social, political and personal sensitivity crucial for a role as change agent (manager or consultant).

How do we do that? In a first trajectory a varied range of perspectives is offered that will highlight paradigmatic patterns of thought involved in the way change is conceptualized in organisations and society at large. This includes considerations of multi-level processes and the complexity of social behaviours in change. The second trajectory treats the theories, concepts, and methods that offer students a frame of reference for the diagnosis and handling of differences in change situations. This includes the consideration of multiple perspectives, agendas, expectations and politics, as well as the (explicit or implicit) impact of disparate social and organizational contexts. The third trajectory is used to engage students in situations where they may experience change and actually work with the concepts, methods and instruments offered throughout the course. Cases, documentaries, TV and film fragments invite students to search for their own relational practice, to experience and diagnose a specific change situation directly, and to analyse and understand the meaning and contexts of the particular situation. Related to a practical case chosen during the course, methods of perception, reflection, intake, diagnostics and intervention are practised and explained.

The course is given once per week, alternating between theoretical and methodological lectures. Theoretical lectures review relevant theories on change and analyses their relation with organizational change. In these theoretical lectures the connections with debates in change studies are made visible and tested for their applicability to organizational change.

In the methodological lectures we look into methodological questions relevant for a change agent: how do we develop a change attitude? How do we observe, listen, diagnose and analyse different change situations when we take the positions and theories reviewed in the first lectures take seriously? The main emphasis in these lectures is on creating practical knowledge and insights, as well as sensitivity to how the own stance of change agent affects their choices, foci and behaviours.

In this course, study and inquiry will be done in teams of five students. Each week the teams are asked to write a short analysis on the main characteristics, similarities, and differences of the treated theories. Teams also do field work in a real-life project, which teams will be asked to inquire and present. In a final paper, teams report on their overall diagnosis and findings from their project. Finally, students are asked to present their individual personal lessons in a self-assessment paper.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The Learning Objectives for this course are:

column2: To look at and understand social behavioural processes in organisational change where plurality and synchronicity are actual items
To enable students to experience, analyze and understand change as systems of interlinked organizations and stakeholders in more or less profound, continuous transition
To support students to develop a theoretical basis to understand, analyze and prepare change in diverse organisational and social contexts
To provide students with a toolbox of methods to evaluate change processes and outcomes
To test out and practice the role of change agents in a real-life project
Be able to analyze the relevant social and political context of organizational changes
Be able to prepare, diagnose and guide change processes cognitively, as well as socially
Be able to relate perspectives of change to diagnosis methods of change, and combine different diagnosis methods in particular change situations

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The master’s thesis is the final part of the master program. During this final phase, students apply their knowledge and skills in the field of pedagogical and educational research. By formulating relevant academic research questions and carrying out a subsequent research, students contribute to the collective knowledge base of professionals and academics in the field of pedagogy and education.

The master thesis is an academic written product, an academic aptitude test in which students reflect their academic level. The master thesis describes empirical research in form of an academic article and contributes to the knowledge of pedagogical or educational science.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: current insights, key theories, empirical findings, and national and international developments, both within the chosen specialization and at the interface of the three specializations (i.e. ortho pedagogy, family pedagogy and educational sciences);

cultural (i.e. ethnic-cultural, ethical and/or legal), economic, social and/or political developments within the chosen specialization, and related issues, problems and findings (including empirical findings);

advanced methods and models used in the process of signaling and identifying complex, multi-problem pedagogical situations and providing appropriate guidance and support, both at the level of the individual and at the level of systems and institutions;

intervention (or treatment) models of complex, multiple pedagogical problems, including their effectiveness and their application in a diverse context (i.e. diversity in ethnic-culture, social-economic status, legislation, language, gender);
advanced designs and methods for social sciences research.
Students are able to:
<li>

column6: assess and translate complex pedagogical problems into interventions, programs and/or policy, and  analyze and evaluate them;

column5: <li>

column6: carry out research within the chosen specialization and at the interface with other related sub disciplines of the pedagogical sciences;

column5: <li>

column6: analyze complex questions, issues and developments in the field of upbringing and education and form a well-reasoned opinion by integrating existing knowledge and their own understanding with the ability to reflect on the limitations of their knowledge and on the influence of their own and other people’s culture-based norms and values;

column5: <li>

column6: carry out their pedagogic and scientific work with an awareness of ethical and culture-related aspects, in respect of clients as well as test subjects, and to oversee the consequences of their own professional actions;

column5: <li>

column6: work in a multidisciplinary group in a pedagogical context, and competently take on either a leading role or a team role;

column5: <li>

column6: communicate complex themes, either orally or in writing, in a clear and comprehensible way, with the ability to differentiate between different target groups (e.g. children, parents, teachers, policymakers, scientists and other professionals) and accounting for diversity;

column5: <li>

column6: keep up with subject-related developments and developments in society in order to contribute to change processes in pedagogic practice and to innovation in the field of pedagogy; independently engage in a further specialist study program and continue working on their professional development.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Mundus MAPP includes a significant research training and independent research component, preparing students for further studies and/or jobs requiring research skills following graduation.

Work on the student’s research project starts with a short statement of thesis topic, submitted to ISS/CEU by 1 February of year one, stating a preference for a supervisor at the first year institution, who will act as primary supervisor in academic year one. In the following month, a second supervisor from York/IBEI will be allocated to the student, with this faculty member taking over primary supervisory responsibilities from the ISS/CEU supervisors when students progress from year 1 to 2. The two supervisors will collaborate and jointly advise the student during the two years of the program until the thesis is submitted.

The thesis report should be written after coursework finishes in the first academic year. The report serves as an advanced thesis proposal which already covers considerable ground for the thesis itself, to be written in year two. The report will be a paper of 6,000 words (including all references, footnotes, bibliography, appendices, and abstract), which includes a problem specification (research question/ rationale), initial literature review, methods and, where appropriate, hypotheses and case study selection; as well as work plan detailing deadlines the student intends to observe for writing up the different parts of the thesis. The topic of the thesis report (and by extension the thesis) should be relevant to the student’s mobility track.

The report is due by 1 September of year two, and is jointly graded by the two supervisors, each contributing half the final grade. Students receive detailed comments from the graders, and a single grade allocated in the ISS/CEU grading scheme.
The thesis report should achieve the following:

column5: Lead us into the general, then the specific topic.
Indicate that there is a gap, an area or puzzle that is unanswered or unresolved.
State the research question (as a question, where methodologically appropriate).
Indicate briefly how this question will be answered (i.e. what methods you have chosen).
Point to the value of this research, either practical (how it will benefit policy) or academic (how it will advance our knowledge).
Provide a review of relevant literature and indicate how it well help you deal with the chosen topic.
Provide a work plan with deadlines and deliverables up to the end of the thesis writing period.

column3: The thesis report will be marked in the ISS or CEU marking system, using the following assessment criteria:

column5: Problem specification: Is the research question to be pursued in the thesis clear and suitable?
Does the thesis report provide a convincing rationale for pursuing the proposed research?
Presentation of concepts / theory: Does the report identify a suitable approach/theoretical framework/key concepts that will guide the thesis?

Literature review: does the report identify relevant body/bodies of literature? Does it show a good understanding of appropriate/relevant literature? Is the literature competently reviewed, and its relevance for the thesis well established?

Research design and methods: Is the report explicit about the research design of the planned thesis, including, where appropriate, hypotheses and case study selection? Does it provide a good discussion of planned data collection and analysis, of sources and methods that will be used? Are the chosen method/s well justified?
Referencing: Is the use of literature and sources competent? Is referencing in line with good scholarly standards?
General presentation: Is the report neatly presented and clearly structured? Is the language clear and correct? Is the report within (and not significantly shorter than) the expected 6,000 words?
Quality of work plan: Does the thesis report include a realistic work plan and time table towards completion of the thesis, of the major milestones and deliverables?

presented a convincing proposal for the final thesis including a statement regarding the objectives of the research, the research question, a short review of the relevant theoretical background and a statement on the methodology.

column1: The final thesis takes the form of an individual research project. The topic can be chosen by the student, but it needs to be related to one or more of the GMD and PA courses in their track. The thesis must cover a governance issue in relation to migration and diversity, making use of the public administration literature to analyse a specific governance approach. For instance, a comparative analysis of how and why different countries or cities promote inter-ethnic contact, or an analysis of the impact of superdiversity on integration policymaking. Note that an internship is not part of our program.

The thesis trajectory consists of two parts: the thesis-proposal and the thesis-research. During this course [thesis-research] the students will execute the data-collection (where relevant) and analysis for the research question they formulated in the previous course and write their thesis in accordance to the academic standards. The process will be supervised in thesis circles where the proceedings are discussed with the supervisor and peers.

Students will be matched with a supervisor, most likely one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of this master program. This is coordinated by the GMD managing coordinator and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>In the process of conducting the research necessary to answer the research questions, and reporting on the study conducted, students learn:

column2: • to independently conduct the empirical analysis on secondary or primary (self-collected) data, using relevant methods and techniques;
• to independently draw and report academically sound conclusion(s) in relation to the research question and public administration and migration-literature;
• to reflect on the conclusion in terms of limitations, theoretical and/or practical implications, and the need for further research;
• to be able to clearly and adequately communicate the main findings of the study to both an expert and a lay audience.
• to clearly structure and fully reference a thesis.

In order to complete the Master of Health Care Management, students are required to write a scientific Master thesis on a topic that is related to one of the subjects covered in the HCM Master. Students write their Master thesis under supervision of a member of the HCM staff. Each supervisor has between 4-6 students that conduct research on a specific theme related to the learning goals of the master HCM. Students may enroll in one of the thesis groups before starting their thesis trajectory. During block 3 through 6, group meetings will be organized -both supervised and unsupervised- during which progress as well as bottlenecks in the thesis process will be discussed.

The thesis trajectory is organized in one course: MSc Thesis. The thesis plan and thesis itself have a workload of 5 and 15 ECTS respectively and thus constitute a major part of the curriculum. The written thesis plan is graded by a PASS or NO PASS. A PASS for the thesis plan is required to start writing the thesis. The evaluation of both the thesis and the defence is conducted by the student's reading committee, which includes the supervisor and at least one co-reader. A pass of supervisor as well as the reading committee is required before the oral defence of the thesis. The written thesis and oral defence of the thesis should be awarded a minimal 5.5 grade.

<body>The objective of the Master thesis is to show that the student is able to perform scientific research individually and to report the study and its conclusions in a clear way.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: De master GMCS wordt afgerond en bekroond met een masterscriptie. De thesis vormt het bewijs van vakbekwaamheid bij het integreren van kennis, en het toepassen van kennis om de bestuurlijke complexiteit te begrijpen en er over te adviseren. De scriptie dient wetenschappelijk verantwoord te zijn. De student toont aan in staat te zijn een bestuurskundige probleemstelling op academisch niveau te kunnen onderzoeken en daarover helder te rapporteren. Het scriptieonderzoek wordt uitgevoerd bij een stageorganisatie. Tijdens de stage doen de studenten mee met het werk van de stageorganisatie, ontwikkelen zij een professionele werkhouding en voeren ze tegelijkertijd, in opdracht van hun tijdelijke werkgever, een onderzoek uit dat de basis vormt voor hun scriptie (zie ook de studiegidstekst voor het Atelier Professionele Vorming en de studiegidstekst voor de stage).

Het afstudeertraject wordt in seminars ondersteund. Deze seminars zijn opgenomen in het atelierprogramma. De scriptiebegeleiding vindt plaats in scriptiekringen van 3-5 studenten die verwante afstudeerprojecten doen. Elke afstudeerkring wordt begeleid door een docent. In principe moeten de scripties medio juli afgerond zijn om in september af te studeren.</body>

column1: Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
• zelfstandig een relevante probleemstelling formuleren voor de stageorganisatie;
• zelfstandig wetenschappelijke literatuur gebruiken om empirisch materiaal op een verantwoorde wijze te analyseren;
• zelfstandig een methodologische verantwoording geven van de keuzes in het onderzoek;
• verschillende empirische bevindingen koppelen aan theoretische concepten;
• zelfstandig (een) conclusie(s) formuleren in aansluiting op de vraagstelling;
• zelfstandig aanbevelingen formuleren op basis van empirische bevindingen en theoretische aspecten;
• een persoonlijke reflectie geven ten aanzien van het eigen onderzoek;
• zelfstandig een onderzoeksrapportage schriftelijk presenteren volgens wetenschappelijke standaarden.

column1: The deliberate and purposeful use of imagination and creativity is indispensable in analytic philosophy. In this course we introduce, analyze and discuss various examples of such thought experiments, focusing on
Students develop the academic skills to put “thought experimentation” into practice, i.e., to use their own imagination and creativity for scientific and philosophical purposes.

column1: (1) The student can recognize and define the main notions, distinctions, problems and “isms” from analytic philosophy.
(2) The student can identify and apply the main views, arguments, objections and authors to episodes, cases and excerpts from analytic philosophy.
(3) The student can formulate, situate and justify the student’s own opinions on key issues in analytic philosophy.
(4) The student can develop and defend a view on the roles of imagination in the student’s own discipline.
(5) The student is able to write a Socratic dialogue in which an analysis of a philosophically relevant concept is put to the test by means of a thought experiment.

Tijdreeksanalyse is het vakgebied dat zich bezighoudt met het modelleren van sequentiele waarnemingen van economische variabelen, zoals maandelijkse werkloosheidcijfers. Een dergelijk model kan worden gebruikt voor het doen van voorspellingen en voor het inschatten van mogelijke gevolgen van beleid. Centraal staat hierbij de dynamische samenhang tussen economische ontwikkelingen (bijv. trends, seizoeninvloeden, conjunctuurcycli).
De voornaamste onderwerpen die in dit vak aan bod komen zijn:

column2: • De keus van de dynamische structuur van een tijdreeksmodel

column1: Time series analysis concerns modelling sequential observations on economic variables, such as monthly unemployment figures. A suitable time series model can be used for making forecasts and for policy analysis. A key issue in developing a suitable model for time series concerns the dynamic features of economic variables, such as trends, seasonal fluctuations, and business cycles.
The main topics covered in this course are:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Learn the basics of time series analysis.
• Learn econometric techniques for modeling and forecasting economic time series data.
• Learn to apply time series models for describing and forecasting economic time series.
• Develop skills to do model specification, parameter estimation and inference, specificiation testing, and forecasting.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Dit vak geeft een inleiding in beschrijvende statistiek, waarschijnlijkheidsrekening en verklarende statistiek. Er wordt aandacht besteed aan toepassingen van de statistiek in de economie. Onderwerpen die aan de orde komen zijn beschrijvend-statistische maatstaven voor één variabele en de grafische voorstellingen ervan, samenhang tussen twee variabelen en lineaire regressie.

Onderwerpen uit de waarschijnlijkheidsrekening zijn kansrekening, de stelling van Bayes, verdelingen van kansvariabelen, waaronder de Poisson verdeling die een belangrijke rol speelt bij de analyse van wachttijdproblemen.

Verder wordt aandacht geschonken aan het schatten van het gemiddelde van een kwantitatieve variabele en aan het toetsen van hypothesen over dit gemiddelde zowel met als zonder een bekende standaarddeviatie. Ook komt een toets op het verschil in proporties aan de orde.
Tijdens de practica krijgen de studenten gelegenheid te werken aan opdrachten die betrekking hebben op de behandelde stof en die representatief zijn voor het examen.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Verwerven van basiskennis van statistische methoden en technieken.
• Het ontwikkelen van een kritische beoordeling van het kwantitatieve denken in een zakelijke omgeving en economie.
• Ontwikkellen van een mogelijkheid om elementaire statistische methodologie toe te passen. In het bijzonder, in staat zijn om elementaire hypothesetesten uit te voeren.
• Ontwikkelen van het vermogen om betekenisvol statistische bevindingen te interpreteren in een bedrijfs- en economie setting.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Dit vak vormt de brug tussen de voornamelijk beschrijvende statistiek (in FEB11005 - Toegepaste Statistiek 1) en het doen van zelfstandig wetenschappelijk onderzoek (bij FEB12012 Methoden en Technieken, FEB12013 Onderzoeksproject,  bij de werkcolleges, in de Master programma's, bij de scriptie, en later in de werkpraktijk).

Het vak behandelt statistische methoden en modellen die vaak worden toegepast in de economie, waarbij de juiste aanpak afhangt van de vraagstelling en van de aard van het beschikbare cijfermateriaal. De voornaamste onderwerpen zijn de volgende: toetsen, kruistabellen, ANOVA, niet-parametrische toetsen, regressie (enkelvoudig en meervoudig, tijdreeksen).
Bij de practica worden opdrachten gemaakt en besproken, waarbij practicumpunten vallen te verdienen. Studenten passen verder statistiek zelf actief toe met software.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De student leert de basisprincipes (beschrijven, schatten en toetsen) en de praktische toepassing van statistiek in de (algemene en bedrijfs-) economie.
• De student maakt kennis met het gebruik van statistische gegevens en modellen voor het wetenschappelijk toetsen van gezichtspunten en het verantwoord onderbouwen van beslissingen.
• De student leert statistische modellen en methoden actief toe te passen met behulp van het statistische pakket SPSS.
• De student wordt voorbereid op zelfstandig statistisch onderzoek in situaties waar de student zelf de onderzoeksvragen formuleert en zelf een model opstelt.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85802,2019,Toegepaste micro-economie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. J Delfgaauw', 'prof.dr. AJ Dur']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het vak bestaat uit twee onderdelen: personeelseconomie en publieke economie.

column2: • Het eerste deel van het vak bestudeert prikkels voor en motivatie van werknemers in organisaties. De rol van monetaire en niet-monetaire prikkels in het motiveren, selecteren en aantrekken van werknemers staat centraal. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn: de effecten van prestatiebeloning op de motivatie en selectie van werknemers, optimaal aanname- en doorstroombeleid, onderwijs, werken in teams, promotie-toernooien, pensioenen en andere secundaire arbeidsvoorwaarden.

• Het tweede deel van de cursus richt zich op het functioneren van markten in het geval van publieke goederen, externaliteiten, en asymmetrische informatie, en de rol van de overheid in het verminderen van de inefficiëntie die ontstaat wanneer markten niet perfect functioneren. De beperkingen van overheidsinterventies worden ook bestudeerd, evenals de effecten van belastingen en inkomensherverdeling. Tenslotte wordt de normatieve discussie van overheidsinterventie aangevuld met een positieve analyse van collectieve besluitvorming.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: Begrijpen hoe economische theorie gebruikt kan worden met betrekking tot het werven, selecteren en motiveren van werknemers in organisaties.
Begrijpen hoe economische theorie gebruikt kan worden voor het bestuderen van het functioneren van markten bij markfalen en de gevolgen van overheidsingrijpen voor efficiëntie en verdeling.

Het toepassen van concepten en technieken die geleerd zijn bij de eerstejaarsvakken Micro-economie en Wiskunde 1 en 2 voor het analyseren van de effecten van voorgestelde reacties op problemen die besluitnemers tegen komen in de collectieve sector in het bijzonder en in organisaties in het algemeen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87887,2019,Toga en spoed,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. B de Jong', 'mr.dr. JC de Wit', 'prof.mr. PAM Mevis', 'prof.mr.dr. JS Nan']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In de rechtspraktijk is spoed soms van het grootste belang, maar (te) haastige spoed ook weer niet altijd goed. In de praktijk van het TOGA-beroep zijn er tal van momenten waarop met een voorlopige voorziening belangen op korte termijn effectief moeten worden gewaarborgd. Daarbij kan het gaan om beslagprocedures of het juist voorkomen van beslag, van schorsing van besluiten van overheidsorganen, en, als niets meer helpt, het voeren van een kort geding of het op z’n minst effectief dreigen daarmee. In alle terreinen van het recht is de nodige spoed en voortvarendheid een eis van goede rechtspraak. Niet tijdig beslissen heeft consequenties en overschrijding van de redelijke termijn nog meer. Maar tegen te snel beslissen, bijvoorbeeld te snel beslag leggen of te snel een strafzaak afdoen binnen de ZSM-aanpak, moet ook worden gewaakt. In het vak Toga en spoed komt dus enerzijds het bewaken van de voortvarendheid van procedures aan de orde en anderzijds is er aandacht voor de mogelijkheden om te waken tegen te grote spoed.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het doel van het vak toga en spoed is de verschillende elementen en procedures aan de orde te stellen die eenieder die een TOGA-beroep uitoefent paraat moet hebben om, indien noodzakelijk, de op het spel staande belangen in spoedprocedures veilig te stellen of zich daar juist tegen te verweren. Hiertoe wordt onder andere gewerkt met opdrachten die zien op het vervaardigen van processtukken in de diverse procedures uit en in de diverse rechtsgebieden (interne rechtsvergelijking).

FW Bleichrodt', 'prof.mr. PAM Mevis', 'prof.mr. SD Lindenbergh', 'prof.mr.dr. HN Schelhaas', 'prof.mr.dr. JS Nan']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In dit vak zal in het bijzonder aandacht worden besteed aan de bewijsvergaring, de bewijswaardering door de rechter, de bewijslastverdeling en het leerstuk van het onrechtmatig verkregen bewijs. Denk bij onrechtmatig verkregen bewijs aan de situatie waarin de overheid door vormfouten bewijs tegen een burger verkrijgt. Ook weten burgers soms onderling iets van elkaar, terwijl ze dat eigenlijk niet behoorden te weten. Mag dat soort informatie dan gebruikt worden in een civiele, bestuursrechtelijke en/of strafrechtelijke procedure? Is de rechter in het ene rechtsgebied gebonden aan een eerder oordeel van een andere rechter? Daarnaast speelt de mogelijke inbreuk op de waarheidsvinding in dit vak een belangrijke rol. De waarheid behoort steeds gevonden te worden, zodat een goede uitkomst tot stand kan komen. Maar dat kan niet ten koste van alles geschieden: hoever moet het recht of de rechter in het achterhalen van de waarheid gaan?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit vak worden de theoretische uitgangspunten van bewijs en waarheidsvinding bezien vanuit de verschillende rechtsgebieden. De student moet de verschillende bewijsstelsels in het bestuurs-, straf- en civiele recht kunnen beschrijven en vergelijken.

column1: In applied data analysis, outliers and missing data are frequently occurring problems. Therefore, these two topics are the focus of this course.

As outliers can strongly influence the results of standard statistical analysis, robust methods are presented that allow to simultaneously detect and downweight outliers. The focus is thereby on covariance estimation (e.g., MCD-estimator) and regression (e.g., least trimmed squares, MM-estimator). In addition, theoretical concepts to investigate the robustness of statistical procedures are introduced (breakdown point, influence function).

Different mechanisms generating missing data are discussed, and techniques to estimate (""impute"") missing values are introduced (e.g., nearest-neighbor imputation and regression-based techniques). Furthermore, students learn procedures to incorporate extra uncertainty from imputation into estimating standard errors (e.g., bootstrap, multiple imputation).
Students apply the discussed techniques in practical assignments. For this purpose, students should be able to implement some of the methods themselves.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understanding and interpreting theoretical measures of robustness (breakdown point and influence function)
• Imputing missing values such that the multivariate structure of the data is preserved
• Estimating standard errors taking into account the extra uncertainty from imputation
• Applying robust estimation methods that reduce the influence of outliers

column1: This course will survey academic research in the emerging area of FinTech, an interdisciplinary field which studies the application of Information Technology to the Finance area. The FinTech movement began a decade ago with the publication of Nakamoto’s (2008) proposal for the first successful cryptocurrency, Bitcoin. However, it is now recognized that FinTech builds upon important antecedents such as Haber and Stornetta’s (1991) introduction of blockchains and distributed ledgers and Szabo’s (1997) ideas for smart contracts. We will survey the foundational literature of cryptocurrency, blockchains, smart contracts, consensus protocols, and related regulatory issues.  Applications of FinTech in areas such as corporate finance, central banking, investment management, real estate, supply chain management, and personal finance will be studied. We will draw upon the academic literature currently being featured in numerous research conferences and special issues of some of the leading peer reviewed journals.  We will conduct some hands-on data exercises using live FinTech data from public blockchains.

Please note that the Netherlands is a particularly active contributor to FinTech with important applications being introduced in locations such as the Port of Rotterdam: https://www.cryptocoinsnews.com/europes-largest-shipping-port-launches-blockchain-field-lab/

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>To acquaint students with the fundamentals of blockchains, digital currency, smart contracts, initial coin offerings and other important FinTech topics, while providing an overview of the new academic literature in this area.  The importance of ideas such as crowdfunding, decentralization, algorithmic governance, and financial disintermediation will receive special attention.</body>

<body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:

column2: • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

column1: Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Introduce key concepts and problems in the philosophy of science.
• Develop the capacity of students to critically evaluate concepts and approaches in management science with regards to fundamental problems in the philosophy of science.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87043,2019,Total War,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'prof.dr. RD Futselaar']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The phrase ‘Total War’ can be traced back to the 1936 publication of General Ludendorff’s Der Totale Krieg. The concept, however, reaches back as far as Clausewitz’s classic work Vom Kriege, in which he used the words ‘absoluter Krieg’. Clausewitz described a form of war which differed to a great extent from earlier wars. In an absolute war a nation was completely and in all its aspects involved in the war, which aimed at the complete destruction of the enemy with all possible means. Such a war could only end, according to Clausewitz, after one of the belligerents had been completely destroyed. In the historical literature the two World Wars in the Twentieth Century are often described as total wars in terms of the intensity of the struggles, the scope of the conflicts, the nature of the goals, and the extent to which civilians were involved. However, also earlier wars in the late nineteenth century showed features of this all-embracing form of warfare. Military historian Jeremy Black nonetheless argues that 1860-1945 period was markedly different from the warfare that characterized earlier periods; and that it is very different from the situation that has evolved ever since.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The aim of this course is to investigate the unlimited scope of total war in which all available resources of belligerents nations were mobilized and little or no differentiation was made between soldiers and civilians. During this course social, economic, political, military, and technological aspects of total warfare will be explored. The students acquire active knowledge to be able to discuss the major topics of this course, and, eventually will be able to put several aspects of modern warfare in a historical context.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Transmedia Entertainment and Marketing represents a process where different media platforms are combined to disperse unique content and produce a story for a media product or consumer brand or global/social issue. What this means is that the story introduced in a film is expanded through television, novels, and comics; its world is explored through game play or experienced as an amusement park attraction and so forth. This facilitates unique entertainment experiences, active audience engagement and civic participation as well as builds successful media franchises.

Transmedia is also 360 degrees public relations: allowing companies to produce content on multiple platforms, reach targeted consumers from all angles and most importantly enabling audiences to actively collaborate, engage and interact with the content itself. Furthermore, transmedia strategies have also been highly successful as an alternative approach for raising awareness about global causes, influencing citizen action and civic participation as well as creating social impact.

In this course, we will follow the life cycle of different types of content: media texts, consumer brands, global/social campaigns etc. by examining commercial (webisodes, comics etc.) and grassroots (fan fiction, fan films etc.) texts; narrative structures; active audience engagement; integrated business models; franchises, world building as well as branded entertainment strategies. We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of the recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks.

We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of the quite recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks. In addition, we will look at alternative approaches to using Transmedia strategies for raising awareness about global causes, influencing citizen action and creating social impact.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Transmedia Entertainment and Marketing represents a process where different media platforms are combined to disperse unique content and produce a story for a media product or consumer brand or global/social issue. What this means is that the story introduced in a film is expanded through television, novels, and comics; its world is explored through game play or experienced as an amusement park attraction and so forth. This facilitates unique entertainment experiences, active audience engagement and civic participation as well as builds successful media franchises.

Transmedia is also 360 degrees public relations: allowing companies to produce content on multiple platforms, reach targeted consumers from all angles and most importantly enabling audiences to actively collaborate, engage and interact with the content itself. Furthermore, transmedia strategies have also been highly successful as an alternative approach for raising awareness about global causes, influencing citizen action and civic participation as well as creating social impact.

In this course, we will follow the life cycle of different types of content: media texts, consumer brands, global/social campaigns etc. by examining commercial (webisodes, comics etc.) and grassroots (fan fiction, fan films etc.) texts; narrative structures; active audience engagement; integrated business models; franchises, world building as well as branded entertainment strategies. We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of the recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks.

We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of the quite recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks. In addition, we will look at alternative approaches to using Transmedia strategies for raising awareness about global causes, influencing citizen action and creating social impact.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column1: The course consists of two parts. The first part (80%), is based upon a theme-by-theme analysis of carriage contract, where the various unimodal carriage conventions (Hague-Visby Rules, Hamburg Rules, CMR, CMNI, COTIF-CIM, and Montreal), with a focus on non-maritime transportation,  are compared and contrasted to provide a deeper insight in the various subjects at hand. The second part (20%) consists of a study of capita selecta of passenger transportation.
The themes discussed during the lectures include:

column2: • a general introduction in which an overview is given of the various unimodal conventions which are part of the fragmented law of transport, and in which conceptual distinctions are made between the contracts of carriage, freight forwarding and storage as well as special kinds of contracts of carriage, such as multimodal transport contracts.
• title to sue under contracts of carriage and bills of lading,

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In this class, we investigate the making of heritage in both informal and formal educational settings. The focus will be on processes of heritagization of everyday material culture. Both in the academic field as in the wider heritage domain, there has been a growing interest in the culture of everyday life and ordinary things. Historians and ethnologists study the generational transmission and appropriation of repertoires of everyday material culture, and many museums develop exhibitions on everyday practices, displaying ordinary objects. Also in educational programmes for primary and secondary schools, a growing interest in the topic can be discerned. In the lectures and seminars the findings of historical and ethnological research, exhibition projects and educational programmes will be confronted with each other and discussed in a broader cultural context, with the aim of coming to a better understanding of different forms of heritage making and the role of education in processes of heritagization. A museum visit is part of this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students gain understanding of processes of heritage making in various educational contexts (formal and informal, public and private)
• Students are able to critically and analytically reflect on processes of heritage making and to relate in their reflections to academic and professional discourses on this topic.
• By focusing on a selection of concrete cases, students develop a vision on ethical and practical dilemmas that heritage professionals are confronted  with.

column1: It is the main task of the Chief Financial Officer (CFO) to ensure that the firm has a sufficient amount of access to finance and to ensure financial stability over time. In order to reach this, the CFO is assisted by the Treasury Department. During this course, students are getting familiar with the different activities of the Treasury Department. These activities include

cash management, working capital management, debt management, equity management, investment management and risk management. Cash management includes everything that  the treasurer does in order to ensure a stable cash position both now and in the future. Working capital management discusses the matching of the current assets and current liabilities to ensure a sufficient of liquidity. Debt and equity management discusses the several choices firms have to make when issuing debt or equity respectively. Investment management talks about the possibilities and choices that firms have when they want to invest today’s excess cash to ensure future income. Risk management discusses the several types of risk that firms are exposed to in their daily activities, such as exchange rate risks and interest risk.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course students should be able to:
»      Explain what the main activities of a Treasury Department are;
»      Analyze and explain the (implications of) decisions that firms make with their available treasury;
»      Discuss and decide which financial actions should be taken when doing an important transaction;
»      Judge and analyze the decisions that firms make regarding their cash management, corporate finance and risk management;
»      Create a small business plan regarding a large investments vis-à-vis the company’s treasury position</body>

column1: The world of Data Science is buzzing with exciting innovations and daunting insights. In this extracurricular course, we will focus on understanding the underlying data generating process (DGP). As opposed to solely focusing on Deep Neural Networks, we will go through the process of Data Exploration and Transformation as well. After understanding the dataset at hand, we will introduce a diverse set of possible models. Every lecture will be accompanied by deepening resources. Students will select one group of models to apply to their dataset depending on the aim of the project. After Model Fitting, we discuss Model Validation where we again focus on the interpretability and validity of the model with respect to the underlying DGP.
Each session will consist of a 45 minute lecture, followed by practical coding examples.

• Students are able to fit and interpret machine learning models to discrete and continously labeled datasets;
• Students know the applicability of deep learning models and understand how they work;
• Students know the steps involved in working on a data science project from the data collection to implementation phase</body>

column1: In this course we provide students with the art historical, theoretical and critical tools to come to terms with the artistic production – the visual arts, especially - of the post-war period. In doing so, students get a better understanding of both the arts and the contemporary. Throughout the course students combine theoretical discussions on the status of art (‘What is Art?’) and the nature of periodisation (‘what is the Contemporary?’) with critical analyses of singular artworks by canonical artists such as Duchamp and Warhol, Nam June Paik and Gerhard Richter, Jeff Koons and Damian Hirst as well as visits to galleries, museums and exhibitions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and describe the scholarly debate on the roots of ‘Western Civilization’.
• Formulate a personal position within the scholarly debate.
• Trace the evolution of ‘the Other’ in ‘Western’ and ‘Eastern’ societies from Ancient times to the present.
• Compare concepts of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Trace the current-day iconography of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Discuss the link between Ancient Greek, Muslim and ‘Western’ thinking on the relationship between the spiritual and the temporal.
• Explain the decolonization process in the African continent.
• Critically analyze (political) debates on the role of China in the African continent.
• Explain the basic history of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Discuss the current day cultural, economic and political effects of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Explain Samuel Huntington’s theory of the Clash of Civilizations.
• Position a historically and theoretically underpinned view within the discursive debate on ‘East’ and ‘West’.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: We probably all know children or students with learning disabilities. Perhaps you encounter problems with reading or math yourself. Nowadays it seems more important than ever to be able to do well in school, but unfortunately many children suffer from problems with learning. When we think of learning disabilities, most of us think immediately about dyslexia. However, there are many other learning disabilities. The focus of this course is on two forms of learning disabilities: dyslexia and dyscalculia. To be able to understand what happens with children with dyslexia and dyscalculia, it is of importance to learn about the ‘normal’ development of reading and math skills. During this course you will therefore read scientific literature on questions like: how can we explain dyslexia or dyscalculia? How can we predict reading proficiency or problems with math? We will also address questions like: what does the development of learning to read/to count look like and what does that mean for the instruction of these skills in school?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course you should be able to:

column2: • Reproduce and illustrate the cognitive development of reading and mathematical skills and the role of phonological awareness;
• Describe and compare different instructional methods to teach reading and mathematical skills;
• Explain the characteristics of two subgroups of learning disorders: (1) reading disorders, and (2) math disorders;
• Explain the underlying (risk)factors causing/predicting reading disorders, and math disorders but also normal development;
• Analyze the quality and use of assessment methods that are used to diagnose reading disorders, and math disorders;
• Analyze the quality and use of interventions and treatment of reading disorders, and math disorders.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90719,2019,Understanding International Urban Policy,Engels,Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS),,['CG Garrido Veron', 'ir. SM Ruijsink, MSc', 'OFF Fika']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In 2016 the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were adopted, and the New Urban Agenda (NUA) was adopted at the Habitat III conference in Quito. Both policies stand as a shared vision and blueprint for a more sustainable, integrated and prosperous future planet. They address vital issues ranging from poverty eradication, equality, sustainable human settlements, actions to reduce the effects of climate change, etc. SDG’s and NUA rightfully callsfor  an integrated approach, where no one is left behind!

But what are those international urban policies really about? Why was it necessary to develop them at that time? Who is involved or expected to take action in achieving the goals? In what ways, cities benefit from them and do they influence actual urban development processes? These are some of the questions urban actors are asking since they want to know if and how they can be implemented on different levels of intervention to attain a sustainable future for all. Therefore, it has become necessary and even urgent to familiarise oneself on the SDG’s and NUA.

In this course, you will be introduced to what the SDGs and NUA are: how they came into place, the basis for their development and what they are all about. The course provides a platform to question, analyse, reflect and discuss what the policies do and can do for urban practice and the future of cities and its inhabitants.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of the elective, students should be able to:

column2: • Understand and be able to explain the historical context behind the formulation and adaptation of the Sustainable Development Goals and the New Urban Agenda (Habitat III)
• Explain the urban dimension of the Sustainable Development Goals and its potential influence on urban development processes in practice
• Analyse the key components of the Sustainable Development Goals and New Urban Agenda and its potential influence on urban development processes in practice
• Critically evaluate the importance, relevance and (potential) impact of international urban policy for addressing urban challenges (of the future)
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: How can we analyse politics across countries? Why do we speak about left and right wing political parties? Does it matter whether one lives in a republic or in a monarchy? Can ordinary citizens really change the way they are governed? Politics is a defining feature of all human societies. Yet, it is notoriously hard to define because it is so multi-facetted.

This introductory course in comparative politics allows you to learn about basic concepts of political science across a range of political systems. It will also introduce you to comparative methodology: does political power lie with a president, prime minister or parliament? The comparative method guides most politics courses at EUC, and is widely employed across the social sciences.

The core of the course will cover the most common political systems. You will learn how to distinguish between regime types, different electoral systems, and key aspects of political behaviour and culture. Finally, key contemporary issues structuring politics across the world will be examined: the role of ideology, populism, the opposition between democracy and authoritarianism.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

column2: • differentiate between a variety of political systems found across the world
• identify political actors and analyse their behaviour
• retrieve and critically analyse sources of political information

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87668,2019,Understanding health behaviour,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. AE Attema', 'dr. SA Lipman']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: People generally attach great importance to their health and would name it as one of the key aspects for a happy life. Nonetheless, many people do not adhere to a healthy lifestyle and therefore seem to behave in conflict with their own life goals. Smoking, physical inactivity, rejecting vaccination and screening or not adhering to physicians’ recommendations are popular examples. This raises the question as to how we can change behaviour and improve health and wellbeing. This is a question of concern to individuals, schools, companies and governments, and is the central question in this minor. The past decades have seen many different approaches as to how behaviour change can potentially be realised. Traditionally in many fields, but economics especially, individuals are seen as ‘rational decision-makers’, i.e. they know what they want, and make reasoned choices to achieve their goal of a better health and happiness. In this view, policies or interventions to promote behaviour change are only necessary when individuals are misinformed or choice is limited.
In particular, two issues arise that are the focus of this minor:

column2: • The approach to behaviour and what incentivizes behaviour change employed in traditional economics often times does not apply successfully to health, as for most people health is very different from most other commodities. Questions of how to approach issues in health are the domain of health economics, which is one of the core components of this minor.

• We all know that often people do not behave rationally when it concerns their own health and wellbeing. Understanding such non-rational behaviour requires insights from for example psychology and sociology, which are both central to behavioural economics – the second core component of this minor.

column1: You will be introduced to the key concepts from behavioural and health economics, with examples related to health and healthcare. We will apply these concepts to i) understand health behaviour, both rational and non-rational, and ii) explore what this means for individuals, organisations and governments aiming to promote healthier behaviour (e.g., through nudging, boosting, incentives and regulation). Using these insights, you will select an actual health issue of your interest (e.g., excessive drinking, smartphone use in traffic), design an intervention, and reflect on it critically.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Explain the traditional economic approach to rational choice, and discuss the merits and limitations of this approach for understanding and changing behaviour.
• Explain why behavioural and health economics exist as separate disciplines, and discuss how they differ from traditional economics.
• Give examples of heuristics and biases in intertemporal choice, risky choice, and social choice that violate traditional assumptions about rationality.

• Apply these behavioural insights to understand and analyse health behaviour, in at least three settings: lifestyle choice, patient and physician decision-making, and preferences for health and wellbeing.

• Differentiate between, provide arguments for and against, and give examples of appropriate applications in health for the following four common (policy) interventions: a) nudging, b) boosting, c) (financial) incentives, d) regulation.
• Apply insights from behavioural and health economics to develop and evaluate an intervention aimed at promoting health and/or wellbeing.
• Discuss challenges to promoting health and wellbeing for individuals, organisations and governments, such as cost-effectiveness and ethical considerations.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90815,2019,Urban Competitiveness and Resilience,Engels,Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS),,"['BG Calzada Olvera', 'dr. J Fransen', 'dr. P Nagler', 'I Lionggo, MSc', 'prof.dr. FG van Oort']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course is divided into two modules that are taught in parallel:

The first module covers the areas of urban economic competitiveness and resilience from a theoretical as well as an applied point of view. In the field of competitiveness, theories on regional economic competition and competitiveness will be introduced and winners and losers of regional competition discussed. In the field of resilience, students will be exposed to the topics of evolutionary economics, economic transitions and innovation, and placed-based economic development policies.

Each topic will be covered by a lecture followed by two tutorials where students will have the opportunity to discuss concepts and theories in small-scale groups, and to translate these into practical applications working together with their peers. The objective of Module 1 is to gain comprehensive theoretical knowledge in the fields of competitiveness and resilience to be able to critically identify and evaluate local and global issues within urban economies, as well as to tackle these by providing workable solutions.

The second module will run in parallel and cover basic methods of statistical and econometric analysis for policy evaluation. Students will be first introduced to statistical measures, data visualization and probability; and second to the fundamentals of regression analysis, covering univariate and multiple regressions, non-linear regressions and panel data analysis. The major focus of this module lies on the interpretation of results, leading to evidence-based policy making.

Weekly lectures and hands-on tutorials will introduce students to both theory and practice. In each tutorial, students will work with practice data sets using the statistical software STATA to translate knowledge into practice. The objective of module 2 is to gain a solid understanding of quantitative research methods for urban economic analysis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The overall aim of the course is to gain insight into the fundamental urban and regional economic processes that explain economic competitiveness and resilience, as well as to develop the ability to analyze and govern these processes in practice.
More specifically, UCR has the following objectives:

column2: • Reproduce and interpret theories that deal with urban and regional economic competitiveness and resilience.
• Identify criteria for urban and regional economic policy effectiveness using quantitative methods for evaluation.

• Apply economic and geographical reasoning to analyze economic development and governance on various spatial scales: from countries to regions to neighborhoods to households and individuals (macro-level, meso-level and micro-level analyses).
• Apply theories, concepts and analytical research methods from contemporary literature to practical examples.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90650,2019,Urban Competitiveness and Resilience,Engels,Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS),,['BG Calzada Olvera', 'dr. J Fransen', 'dr. P Nagler', 'I Lionggo, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The master thesis is a crucial requirement for obtaining a MSc degree. It demonstrates the student’s ability to perform independent academic research study. With the aim of developing effective strategies for writing a thesis, various instructors specializing in research methodologies have been included as lecturers and facilitators for the workshop. The UCR research workshop is organized in three parts:

column2: • Introduction to the formulation of the research question and how to conduct a literature review, including lectures, discussions and presentations. The first part further includes two colloquia: one focusing on the research question of the thesis, and one focusing on the literature review.

• Usage of methodology, including lectures on survey design, data management and geographically weighted regressions. The second part is finalized with a colloquium on operationalization and methodology.
• Development of students’ analysis skills, finishing with a colloquium where students present their preliminary thesis results.

column1: By offering concrete strategies for an integral thesis writing process, the overall aim of this hands-on research workshop is to guide students in writing their master thesis. More specifically, the research workshop has the following objectives:
•          Start the research project and bring the research project into sharper focus.
•          Find and properly structure literature & come up with a conceptual framework.
•          Operationalize concepts into variables and indicators.
•          Analyze findings into a coherent and well-supported research study.

column1: <body>This course studies the economics of cities and regions at the master level. The aim is to build an overarching framework that helps the student analyse spatial issues like the organization of commuting and transport, firm location choices, land value, and local development. The framework also provides a context for topics dealt with later in the master, for instance in courses on transport, city marketing, real estate and the seminar. To build an understanding of these, we use the microeconomics of agglomeration forces and how they arise, individuals’ location choices, and spatial strategies of firms; and see how they interact. The course considers urban models for individual cities, then moves to systems of cities, and discusses the role of transport. The course uses lectures complemented with small-scale tutorials.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Reproduce and interpret theories of urban and regional economics, dealing with economic policy.
• Identify criteria for urban and regional economic policy effectiveness in ex-ante and ex-post evaluation
• Apply economic reasoning to analyse economic policies on various spatial scales: from countries to neighbourhoods
• Apply theories, concepts and research methods from contemporary literature to practical examples

column1: The UESC specialisation comprises six different though highly interrelated key focus areas.
1. Urban environment sustainability and climate change

column2: • Theoretical approaches to governing global environmental challenges
• Sustainable development, sustainable cities and climate change
• Urban air quality, sustainability and climate change

column1: 3. Climate change mitigation and adaptation in urban areas
4. Urban ecosystem services and nature based solutions

column2: • Services, benefits, and values provided by urban ecosystems to urban areas
• Connections between urban ecosystems, ecosystem services, and nature-based solutions in urban areas
• Nature-based solutions to address climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction
• Performance of nature-based solutions against traditional infrastructure based on multiple criteria

column1: 6. Urban environment, sustainability and climate change methodological approaches and data analysis

column1: At the end of the specialisation students will be able to:

column2: • Understand the key theoretical approaches related to sustainable development, sustainable cities and climate change as well as the concepts related to transitions theory within an urban context and how these can be used to influence urban climate change and sustainability.
• Understand the main environmental challenges faces by urban areas in different geographical regions world-wide and related to urban energy, urban water, urban transport and urban air quality.

• Understand and analyse the effects, impacts, and drivers of climate change and resilience in urban areas and understand the principles and frameworks related to the management of urban climate change in both its adaptation and mitigation dimensions.

• Understand the main concepts and principles related to urban ecosystems services and nature based solutions, apply and analyse different tools and methods related to their implementation, and evaluate their performance against tradition infrastructure interventions.
• Understand and apply the main principles and components of urban morphology as well as urban and regional structure and how these influence urban climate change and sustainability.
• Understand and apply different research methods and approaches to the analysis of quantitative and geospatial data relevant to urban environment, sustainability and climate change.
