column1: Following the specialization period, the Urban Environment, Sustainability and Climate Change specialization will organize a Research Workshop to support the participants in the process of thesis development. The Research Workshop will consist of a series of methodological sessions specifically related to urban environment, sustainability and climate change issues, sessions to discuss different aspects and challenges related to developing a research proposal, and sessions in which the participants will receive feedback on their draft thesis.
The methodological sessions will include among others training on:

Other methodological sessions (e.g. project monitoring and evaluation, multiple case study comparative analysis, advanced data analysis approaches and techniques) may be arranged based on the specific research interests of the participants.
The sessions on developing a research proposal will focus on:

column2: • How to formulate researchable and focused questions

column1: In addition, four colloquia will be organized during which the participants will receive feedback on their thesis draft from the UESC staff as well as their peers. The first colloquium will focus on the presentation of the introductory chapter of the thesis including the research questions, the second colloquium will focus on the presentation of the literature review including the conceptual framework, the third colloquium will focus on the presentation of the research methodology including the operationalization of variables and indicators, and the fourth colloquium will focus on the presentation of data analysis including preliminary findings.

column1: The course is organized in 2 distinct modules. Urban governance: starts with an introduction to the complexity of the urban context and then focuses on the changing role of government and other key stakeholders in the governing of and decision making in a city. Students discuss and debate on the key theories that underpin different perspectives on urban governance. The module also looks at the role of local government in the context of decentralisation reforms, and the influences of these reforms on governance. Public Private Partnerships: introduces the concept of Public Private Partnerships (PPP’s) an instrument for urban governance. The students work on a practical case of business planning for PPPs, and use knowledge and skills gained to make key policy decisions on the appropriateness of PPPs in the urban context.

column2: • Urban Governance –this module looks at the nature of cities, and the increasing complexity in cities. It introduces the difference between government and governance, what urban governance is, and the trends in theory and practice on governance. The participants discuss why urban governance is an essential pillar of sustainable development and the different theories that underpin urban governance. Discussions revolve around the current academic debate on the utility of hierarchies versus new public management versus complex decision-making. Participants look at and assess the empirical evidence on both streams of theory and assess the extent to which these approaches have resulted in the outcomes intended at the local level.

• Public Private Partnerships – a mechanism to implement and institutionalize urban policy: Since the 1990’s PPP’s have become an important approach to streamlining cooperation and risk sharing between the public and private sectors, and achieving value for money in service provisions. This module introduces participants to different rationale, objectives and forms of PPP’s. Participants discuss and assess under what conditions PPP’s can be successful vehicles for urban governance and development. They apply a framework to analyse the 'marketability' of PPPs; this framework aids governments to make sound policy decisions related to PPPs.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After the module participants should be able to:

column2: • Differentiate the theories that underpin good governance; and understand the relevance of hierarchies, markets and network governance for urban governance.
• Deliberate on the trends in the nature of the urban context and its implications for governance.
• Distinguish the various forms of decentralization as an instrument of urban governance and analyse the impacts of the shift of power to local governments.
• Discuss, distinguish and debate the rationale for and utility of bureaucracies, vs. new public management vs. complex decision making in the complex world of today;
• Discuss the rationale for public private partnerships as a mechanism for good governance and understand the reasons for a shift to public private partnerships in service provision.
• Discuss the theories that underpins PPPs and understand what PPP’s are;
• Discuss and analyse how and under what conditions PPP’s can be used to institutionalize private sector participation in urban development.

column1: The Lab is divided into three parts, with one part each in Blocks 1, 2 and 3.

In Block 1, the lecturers introduce: the objectives and format of the Lab; basic management tools and skills to be learned; and the simulation game. The simulation provides students with a first practical exposure to complex issues in an urban governance context. In this Block, students will introduce their personal learning goals related to the Lab, which will form one of the evaluation methods at the end of the Lab (using peer review based on Likert scales).

In Block 2, students work on four case study assignments, each of which takes one full day to complete: the assignment is explained in the morning and must be solved by the end of the day. The cases are undertaken in groups. Each case relates to a specific module in the course. In addition, each case tests a specific skill, for example: network analysis; achieving public policy objectives; learning skills; and policy innovations.

In Block 3, students will work on a real-life case for a Dutch municipality, centred on an actual policy question. On a first visit, students will visit the municipality, and municipal officials will explain the question and there will be an opportunity for questions and clarification. During a subsequent visit(s), students can do site research and meet with additional stakeholders if needed. After four days, students will present their findings and proposals to municipal officials. Students’ work will reflect the skills and concepts learned during the modules and the four previous cases in Block 2.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To increase practical abilities to cope with complexity, various actors and contexts.

• To present various ways of dealing with societal problems in a complex urban network system. Participants should be able to evaluate the various instruments they can put into practice and select proper action perspectives in view of the issues and contexts they are faced with.
• To use insights from other modules in the course and challenge the participants to use these models and approaches to analyse the cases presented and advise urban practitioners accordingly.
• To impart basic skills and tools, including co-operation, teamwork, negotiation, co-creating, and network-learning.

column1: The course is organized in 4 different modules:

column2: • Urban Policy – policies for urban development: This module introduces the meaning of ‘policy’ and highlights various approaches towards urban policy. We will look at what makes a policy “urban” as opposed to sectoral, the impact of changing concepts (for example, integration, decentralization, participation, neo-liberal approaches), the influence of major actors and what makes a good policy document.

• Urban Governance – decision making in situations of complexity: In this module, we look at theories underpinning urban governance and focus on trends to networked forms of governance. Network governance is seen as an alternative to markets and rational choice, in a situation of increasing complexity and uncertainty. Government is no longer the lead actor in development, but one amongst many. This implies a new role for government, a role in steering and managing horizontal relations.

• Urban Planning - this module introduces the different meanings and interpretations of 'urban planning' and the urban planner. It highlights trends in planning approaches and zooms into the shift from traditional land use planning towards more strategic forms of planning.

• Public Private Partnerships – a mechanism of governance: Since the 1990’s PPP’s have become an important approach to streamlining cooperation and risk sharing between the public and private sectors, and achieving value for money in service provisions. This module introduces participants to different rationale, objectives and forms of PPP’s. Participants discuss and deliberate on the conditions under which PPP’s can be successful instruments for urban development.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After the module participants should be able to:

column2: • Discuss and describe the key characteristics of complex decision making and the problems associated with complexity; distinguish and compare network governance theory, new public management perspective and rational decision-making and discuss the implications of these differences for government; discuss and analyse the key characteristics of network governance theory; and analyse and apply the concept to practice in  case study.

• Understand the meaning, dimensions and objectives of urban policy, understand the importance of the policy process and tools for implementation, discuss and deliberate on the nature of public interest and who determines it; understand the nature of policy analysis, and analyse policy documents using a set of guidelines.

• Reflect on what planning is and why it is useful; assess different planning approaches and explain what strategic planning is; analyse the implications of these different planning approaches for the role of the planner in the planning process.

• Distinguish and discuss the different theories that underpin Public Private Partnerships (PPPs), in particular the value of neo-liberal economic theory as a framework for PPPs; discuss and identify the key characteristics of and the rationale for PPPs; identify, discuss and analyse the potential pros and cons of partnerships, as well as the issues faced in setting up PPPs in different sectors; distinguish various forms of PPPs and their characteristics.
• Understand the interconnections between the different module components and analyse what these linkages mean in practice;
• Within a multicultural team, jointly discuss and come to decisions that are mutually agreed upon

column1: The research workshop, in addition to the RMT classes and individual supervision, supports the students in the process of developing their research proposal for their theses (Chapter 1,2,3). The support is provided in the form of workshop exercises with short inputs from the lecturers and structured peer review. The focus of the research workshop is on formulating the research problem and the research question (RW1), developing the conceptual framework (RW1), operationalization of main concepts and research methodology (RW2).
This research workshop will build on the competences that are developed in the specialization course, Urban Housing, Equity and Social Justice (UHES).

Housing Justice is the main concept that constitutes the theoretical focus of our specialization. During the specialization period, students learn about the theoretical framework of Housing Justice that draws from theories of social justice and spatial justice and about other main concepts such as 5 Principles of Adequate Housing (5A’s), namely Availability, Affordability, Accessibility, Acceptability and Adaptability.

During the Research Workshop, students gain the skills to critically debate these theories, concepts to draw a conceptual framework for their theses. They learn to contextualize their own research problem within the existing theoretical debates and discuss the applicability of these theories, debates in the context of their own research.

In this workshop, the focus will be on the problem statement, research questions and conceptual framework. The students will learn how to contextualize their research problem and how to formulate good research questions. They will also gain the ability to critically analyze the debates, concepts in literature to build a conceptual framework for their theses.
In this workshop, the focus is on the operationalization of main concepts, choosing a research strategy and suitable data collection methods.
Individual assignments, peer review, workshops on content and with feedback of the lecturers, Colloquium with student presentations and feedback from the lecturers.

column1: The specialization curriculum consist of an introduction, five teaching modules and a cross cutting case study workshop that binds all the modules together. The case study workshop, called Housing Justice, provides the link between the theories and practices studied in class. It is a tailored educational case study that combines the different themes of the specialization in a dynamic and participatory manner, through group work, debates and the application of tools to develop professional skills. The workshop takes place at the end of module one, two, four and five.
The specialization is divided into five main components:

column2: • An introduction to the housing challenges of inequity, informality, injustice and the global housing affordability crisis within the context of the New Urban Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals.
• Module 1 focuses on the governance of the housing sector which includes housing policies, housing trends and changing paradigms, the functioning of the housing sector and housing needs.
• Module 2 focuses on the relationship between the housing sector and the economy, housing finance and housing and land markets.

• Module 3 focuses on the relationship between housing and planning with particular emphasis on socio-spatial (in)justice and outcomes in housing and urban planning such as gentrification, gated communities, socio-spatial segregation etc.
• Module 4 focuses on human settlements and the environment, which includes sustainable and resilient housing and the relationship of the housing sector with climate change.
• Module 5 focuses on the different conventional and non-conventional formal housing approaches and housing informality.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The main objective of the specialization is to evaluate the different (housing) policies and approaches that address the housing challenge.
At the end of the course, participants should be able to argue how the process of housing affects urban households, particularly the poor, and their human settlements by:

column2: • Understanding how the housing sector works from a governance and economic point of view.
• Analysing how formal and informal housing processes influence inequity and injustice in urban areas by:

column3: • Understanding  formal housing policies, including  the paradigm shift in housing policies, the concepts related to the current paradigm and the criticism of the current paradigm in relationship to the housing challenge; and
• Understanding informal housing processes in response to dysfunctional official policies.

column2: • Applying and analysing the principles of adequate housing, namely availability, accessibility, affordability, acceptability and adaptability in housing policies and approaches.
• Critically reflecting on the application of the principles of housing availability, accessibility, affordability, acceptability and adaptability for realizing adequate housing and housing rights.

• Evaluating to what extent current approaches to formal and informal housing address the housing challenge in relation to the provision of adequate housing, equity and socio-spatial justice (i.e. housing justice).

column1: In line with the unique feature of the MSc Programme, participants will be able at the end of the course to link the theory that supports different housing approaches to its translation into practice through the development of different skills, such as case study analysis, group work, communication skills, role playing, and the practical application of different assessment tools such as stakeholder analysis, housing needs assessment and climate change adaptation strategies in housing.

column1: The ULG is organized around three thematic clusters:

column2: • Cluster 1: land rights and the rule of law (weeks 1 and 2 of the specialisation). Content coordinator: Ore Fika.
• Cluster 2: land markets and finance (weeks 3 and 4 of the specialisation). Content coordinator: Paul Rabé.
• Cluster 3: land, water and natural resources (weeks 5 and 6 of the specialisation). Content coordinator: Paul Rabé.

column1: The final week of the specialisation (week 7) is the examination week. During this time, students will present the group work related to the final assignment (on Tuesday of the final week) and prepare the final paper related to the final assignment (due date is on the Sunday following the exam week).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Description and Objectives of the ULG Specialisation

The ULG specialization provides students with a critical understanding of the importance of land governance in supporting sustainable urban development and urban “resilience”, in social, economic and environmental terms. “Land” in this specialisation includes also water and natural resources in cities, which are important components of land markets, be it as platforms of development or as scarce resources to be accessed and/or protected. The specialisation adopts a governance approach to land, water and natural resources: it emphasises the nature and behaviour of urban land governance, the institutions that govern land development, formal and informal regulations, as well as public and private actors that operate in urban areas, which include governments, land holders, real estate developers and land brokers.

The specialisation begins with an analysis of property rights and legal frameworks that enable access to land (Cluster 1). It subsequently advances into an analysis of land markets and the complexity of options that cities have when choosing from a portfolio of land-related instruments in the pursuit of their wider strategic objectives (Cluster 2). Finally, the specialisation delves into the concept of “sustainability” and investigates the integrated package of (institutional, legal and technical) measures needed to properly manage land, water and natural resources in an urban setting (Cluster 3).
At the end of the specialisation students should be able to:

column2: • Critically evaluate the dynamics, including relationships and conflicts, that exist in the governance of land, water and natural resources in connection to land rights, the rule of law, markets, finance, sustainability, and their impacts on urban and peri-urban areas, institutions and stakeholders.
• Propose fit-for-purpose/tailor-made land governance strategies and approaches to achieve inclusive, equitable and resilient urban and peri-urban areas.

column1: USP links theory and practice by introducing conceptual knowledge and theory about strategic planning, planning and complexity, self-organization, informality, spatial justice, and building trust as well as tools and methods employed in action research, particular planning methods, serious gaming and stakeholder negotiation. Participants will apply these skills and reflect on them through working on a case study in Rotterdam. At the beginning of the module, the focus is on building basic competences in spatial and social analysis and on theoretical inputs. Following that, the specialization focuses on engaging with stakeholders in Rotterdam to develop an interactive co-created serious game that gives insights in Rotterdam’s socio-spatial dynamics and allows participants to discuss different strategies for the future.  This game will be then presented, tested and reflected on during a final workshop with urban stakeholders, organized by the participants.
Week 1 Introduction and Development of Socio-Spatial Skills

During this first week participants develop their socio-spatial skills through a series of workshops designed around; social analysis and presentation, spatial analysis and visualisation, and urban observation. At the end of this first week the students will present a socio-spatial analysis of a specified area, which will be used to develop the game board.

Planning theory knowledge is developed in the second week. Throughout the week issues such as; complexity, systems thinking and scale; strategic planning; social and spatial innovation; governance, policies and stakeholders; and urbanisation will be addressed in relation to their relevance in urban planning.

In the third week, participants will develop knowledge on spatial justice and theory, in cooperation with the Urban Housing, Equity and Social Justice specialization. Knowledge is transferred through a series of lectures which addresses topics such as; social justice and inequality; spatial justice; gentrification; counter hegemonic trends (right to the city, city as a commons, sharing city); gender. Based on the learnings of week 2 and 3, participants will present a framework for analysing the qualities of the game.

Spatial planning is approached in the specialization as a multi-stakeholder activity. Therefore, during the fourth week, participants will establish interaction by setting up a dialogue with the main stakeholders. The participants are then given the opportunity to identify relevant stakeholders and prepare and conduct interviews. This will be the basis for the game characters.

Weeks five - six are designed so the participants work on the co-design and development of the game. During this time, the schedule is divided between workshops, lectures which support the game development work, as well as progress meetings. Work on the game development will be structured through several sub-assignments both as group work and individual work.

At the beginning of week 7, the game will be presented to and played with stakeholders. Following this, participants will work on an individual assignment which is to reflect on the process and the outcome of the game development and evaluate the game according to the framework they have developed in week 2 and 3.

column1: The overall learning objective of the course is to engage in reflective practice regarding urban planning and governance and its influence on socio-spatial dynamics.
After completing the course, participants should be able to:
➔ Critically assess socio-spatial dynamics in an urban context, based on specific concepts and theories addressed during the course;
➔ Identify and engage with stakeholders in a planning process and analyse their interests and needs;
➔ Apply concepts and tools related to strategy development, integrating social, environmental, economic, spatial, financial and institutional components of urban plans;
➔ Reflect on the qualities of planning and policies, the interests and values that plans and policies represent and their impact on existing dynamics;
➔ Come up with creative solutions by synthesizing and combining concepts and ideas that critically address socio-spatial dynamics in complex urban problems, individually and in team;
➔ convincingly communicate ideas, plans and arguments, supported by theory, orally, visually and in writing.

• ComplexCity: an introduction to urbanisation processes in history and to the evolution of urban theory and complexity theory.

• A pedagogical game, Gaining with Land Use Transactions (GLUT), whereby key actors negotiate positions in a stylist city mediated by markets and regulations. Here participants have an opportunity to experiment how the complex interrelation of social, economic, environmental and political factors impact on the spatial structure of cities.

• The evolution of cities from different disciplinary perspective: economic, social, spatial and environment. In addition, we will discuss how cities grow informally. The core question addressed is: how do specific disciplines understand the evolution of (aspects of the) city?

column1: When participants are not in class during the GLUT game, they are expected to study on their own. In particular, they can prepare for part 3 and 4 of the course.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: With over half of the world population living in urban areas, rising to 70% in 2050, it is of ever increasing importance to understand how cities evolve over time. Cities are continuously formed and transformed by complex economic, social, physical and environmental processes. Understanding cities requires us to recognize, define and describe these complex and multidisciplinary processes, which are often self-re-organised, non-linear and non-deterministic.
This course discusses why and how cities emerge and change over time. By the end of the course, participants will be able to:

column2: • Apply selected academic perspectives in order to describe why and how cities evolve within different (national) contexts and time periods.
• Compare and contrast the different lenses that the academic perspectives take in order to appreciate urban evolutions.

column1: The course introduces the following academic perspectives: urban theory; complexity theory; urban economic development; urban social development, urban spatial development; and urban environmental development.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The origins of sociological and criminological interest in the relationship between the city and crime can be traced back to the ""Chicago School"" at the beginning of the 20th century. An enormous urban growth at the beginning of the 19th century in the United States, particularly in Chicago, drove urban transformation processes that aroused the interest of the Chicago School's researchers. The city was seen as a laboratory where human behaviour and social processes could be studied closely.

In this module we build on this research tradition by reviving the criminological interest for the city. It is now a hundred years ago that the article ""The City: Suggestions for the Investigation of Human Behaviour in the City Environment"" (1915) by Robert Ezra Park has appeared. Since then, obviously, a lot has changed in 'the city'. In 2012, UNICEF ​​predicted that by 2050 no less than 70 percent of the world population lives in the city. This urbanization, as part of processes of globalization, requires, like the enormous expansion of cities at the beginning of the 19th century, attention for a number of new and changing metropolitan issues. In this module we will zoom in on a number of these recent urban developments – in Europe and beyond – and then in particular in the context of deviance, crime and insecurity.

The module 'Urban issues, culture and crime' offers students an introduction to classical and recent (urban) sociological texts in which the city is central. In the weekly interactive lectures, we discuss different perspectives on the city such as global cities, poor cities, superdivers cities, deviant cities and the gentrified city.</body>
<body>Upon completion of the module, the student will be able:

column2: • Students have up-to-date knowledge from the (urban) sociological scientific literature on cities and urban issues in relation to insecurity and crime,
• Students are able to describe characteristics of urbanity and relate them to (street) culture, deviant behaviour and insecurity,
• Students can describe and interpret the influence and impact of global transformation processes on local practices in world cities,

column1: Students are able to reflect critically on (policy) reactions to urban developments in areas of employment, housing, leisure and safety, in particular in the light of unintended effects of policy.</body>
